Punjab Kings showcased their batting firepower, posting a strong 201/4 on the back of a sensational opening stand.
Priyansh Arya (69 off 35) and Prabhsimran Singh (83 off 49) laid a fearless foundation, combining aggression with timing as they tore into the KKR bowling attack. Arya’s crisp strokeplay and Prabhsimran’s six-hitting spree kept the run-rate above 10 for most of the innings. Shreyas Iyer (25* off 16) and Josh Inglis (11* off 6) provided a late flourish, ensuring PBKS crossed the 200-mark despite a slight slowdown after the openers departed.
For KKR, Vaibhav Arora (2/34) was the pick of the bowlers, though the attack overall lacked control under pressure.

In reply, KKR were 7/0 after 1 over, with Gurbaz and Narine cautiously starting the chase.
However, steady rain and strong winds forced the players off — and eventually, the match was called off.

Matchsummary.MatchName: Chennai Super Kings vs Sunrisers Hyderabad
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Sunrisers Hyderabad Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The spotlight shifts to the MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai as Chennai Super Kings (CSK) take on Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) in Match 43 of the IPL 2025. Both teams are level on points with four each from eight matches and are separated only by net run rate. With the playoff race tightening, a loss here could severely dent either team’s qualification hopes.

CSK have endured a tough campaign, with their top-order woes reflected in a league-low powerplay average of just 45 runs. The bowling unit hasn’t fared much better, especially at the death, where containment has been a constant struggle. Despite their overall form, CSK will draw confidence from their strong home record, having never lost to SRH at Chepauk.

SRH, meanwhile, have fared slightly better in the early overs, averaging 56 in the powerplay. But their campaign has been undermined by patchy performances in the middle overs and a lack of control in the final phase with the ball. Players like Heinrich Klaasen have shown flashes of brilliance, but consistency remains elusive.

The Chepauk pitch is known to aid spin and has produced moderate first-innings scores, typically in the 170s. Dew could play a role later in the evening, making chasing a preferred option for the team winning the toss.

With both sides battling for survival, expect a gripping encounter where every over counts and every mistake could prove costly in this must-win clash.



IPL Stats at MA Chidambaram Stadium Since 2024:


Pitch Report – Simon Doull & Michael Clarke
"We’ve got 70 meters on one side, 63 meters on the other, and 74 meters straight down the ground—a fairly balanced layout, but the short square boundary could come into play for the batters.
The surface looks quite dry—very similar to what we’ve seen here in previous games. It’s expected to be a bit on the slower side, maybe even two-paced. I think bowlers will rely heavily on variations, especially change of pace, and we might even see a bit of turn as the game progresses.

It looks like a tricky pitch, and batting might not be as straightforward as the dimensions suggest."

CSK:- 50/3 (8.33 rpo, 8x4, 0x6) || SRH:- 37/2 (6.17 rpo, 7x4, 0x6)

CSK:- 27/4 (5.58 rpo, 1x4, 1x6) || SRH:- 41/0 (3.4 overs 11.18 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)
 

Sunrisers Hyderabad kept their playoff hopes alive with a crucial five-wicket win over Chennai Super Kings at the MA Chidambaram Stadium. Chasing 155 for victory, SRH reached the target with eight balls to spare, handing CSK yet another home defeat in a season full of struggles.

Earlier, CSK, put in to bat, never quite got the momentum they needed. Shaik Rasheed fell on the very first ball,. Ayush Mhatre showed some intent with a quick 30, and Dewald Brevis sparkled briefly with 42 off 25 balls, hitting four sixes. However, regular wickets, especially in the middle overs, prevented CSK from accelerating. Harshal Patel was the pick of the SRH bowlers, claiming 4/28, while Pat Cummins and Jaydev Unadkat chipped in with two wickets each to bowl CSK out for 154 in 19.5 overs.

In response, SRH lost Abhishek Sharma early, but Ishan Kishan anchored the chase with a composed 44. Contributions from Aniket Verma, Kamindu Mendis (32*), and Nitish Kumar Reddy (19*) ensured SRH stayed ahead of the required rate despite some hiccups. Noor Ahmad was the most successful bowler for CSK with two wickets, but the target proved too modest to defend.

 

MS Dhoni (Chennai Super Kings Captain)

"I think the key issue was that we kept losing wickets at regular intervals.Also, the wicket played better in the first innings. Scoring only 155 wasn’t justifiable. It wasn’t turning much early on—after the 10th over it became slightly two-paced—but we still should have batted better.In the second innings, our spinners bowled well, but we were already 15–20 runs short, which made a big difference. I thought Brevis batted well today. We need someone like him in the middle order—someone who can counter spin effectively.The way we have struggled in the middle overs against spin, it’s crucial we find ways to bat smartly, keep rotating strike, and find boundaries. That’s an area where we need improvement.In a tournament like this, if one or two players are off-form, you can work around it. But when a majority of players are not performing, it becomes very difficult. You try giving players extra chances, but if it doesn’t work, you need to make changes. When four players are struggling at once, you have no choice but to make multiple changes.Going forward, it’s about assessing conditions better and putting enough runs on the board."
 

Pat Cummins (Sunrisers Hyderabad Captain)

"That was a great performance. A few things came together nicely tonight, and it was good to see the boys playing with freedom and a few smiles around. We were pretty clinical overall. A couple of guys at the top looked like they wanted to take the game on, which was exactly what we needed in these conditions. We pushed Klaasen up the order, and Nitish did a brilliant job finishing it off. Our record here hasn’t been great historically, so it’s nice to get a win. Still things we can improve on to be more clinical, but overall, really pleased with the result."
 

Harshal Patel (Player of the Match)

"It’s a very pleasing win. Over the past 3–4–5 games, we’ve been trying to put it all together, but every time, one piece or another was missing. For everything to click when we need it the most, especially with all games now being must-wins, feels really satisfying. I figured out early that hitting a good length and keeping it at the stumps was key on this surface. It was tough for the batters to play horizontal bat shots, so I was trying to make them hit over square leg and mid-wicket. I wasn’t aiming wide outside off—I just focused on bowling into the stumps, and thankfully, it came off tonight. For me, having family around really helps. It allows me to switch off from cricket and reminds me that cricket is not the be-all and end-all. That balance keeps me grounded."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Royal Challengers Bengaluru vs Rajasthan Royals
Matchsummary.Commentss: Royal Challengers Bengaluru Won by 11  Runs
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Rajasthan Royals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.Comments: Royal Challengers Bengaluru Won by 11  Runs
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The 42nd fixture of TATA IPL 2025 brings Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) back to their fortress at the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium, where they face Rajasthan Royals (RR) in a crucial mid-season clash. RCB sits in fourth place with 10 points from eight matches and will be determined to break their home jinx, having lost all three games played at this venue so far.

Their campaign has been powered by Virat Kohli’s consistent run at the top, scoring 322 runs in eight innings, while skipper Rajat Patidar has provided stability with 221 runs in seven outings. Josh Hazlewood led the attack effectively with the ball, bagging 12 wickets and offering control in key phases.

Rajasthan Royals, placed eighth on the table, are desperate for a turnaround after four consecutive defeats. Riyan Parag continues to lead the side in the absence of Sanju Samson, who remains sidelined due to injury. Yashasvi Jaiswal has been their shining light with 307 runs at a healthy strike rate of 139+, but the team has faltered in pressure moments, including a recent failure to chase nine runs in the final over. The Chinnaswamy surface, usually a paradise for batters, has offered unexpected help to spinners this season. With clear skies and the likelihood of dew later in the evening, chasing might be the preferred option.

While RCB enter the contest with momentum and a more settled core, RR will be hoping to halt their slide and revive their playoff aspirations.



IPL Stats At M. Chinnaswamy Stadium Since 2024:


Pitch Report – Eoin Morgan & Simon Katich
"We’re back at the Chinnaswamy Stadium, where the home side is flying—but curiously, not at home. That’s the challenge tonight—can they translate that form onto this surface? Let’s talk dimensions first. We’re bang in the center of the ground—it’s 73 meters straight, and 64 meters square on either side. So, not a lot to choose from in terms of targeting short boundaries.This pitch looks noticeably drier than it did in the previous game against Punjab. I’d say it will play a lot better tonight—perhaps with a bit more evenness to it.That said, the average first-innings score this season is just 166, which tells you there’s still something in it for the bowlers—especially the quicks.Interestingly, across all venues this season, Chinnaswamy has been the most effective for seamers. It’s been a little two-paced at times, with extra bounce, especially for taller bowlers like Hazlewood and Marco Jansen, who got good rewards here.However, looking at tonight’s strip, there’s not much tufty grass left, so I expect it to be a better surface for batting.Just for perspective—last season’s average first-innings score here was 197, which is significantly higher than what we’ve seen so far this year."




Toss Update: RR Won the toss and elected to field first! 

 

???? Toss ????@rajasthanroyals elected to field against @RCBTweets

Updates ?? https://t.co/mtgySHh88K #TATAIPL | #RCBvRR pic.twitter.com/8JwwIHyOmh

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 24, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (over 1-6)
RCB:- 59/0 (9.8 rpo, 9x4, 0x6) || RR:-72/2 (12 rpo, 7x4, 6x6)

Middle overs (over 7-15)
RCB:- 97/1 (10.8 rpo, 7x4, 5x6) || RR:-76/2 (8.44 rpo, 7x4, 3x6)

Death overs (over 16-20)
RCB:- 49/3 (9.8 rpo, 6x4, 1x6) || RR:-46/5 (9.2 rpo, 3x4, 3x6)
 

Royal Challengers Bengaluru held their nerve to edge past Rajasthan Royals by 11 runs in a high-scoring contest at the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium, snapping their home losing streak and climbing further up the points table.

After being put in to bat, RCB posted a commanding 205/5 on the back of a solid platform laid by Virat Kohli and Devdutt Padikkal. Kohli played the anchor role to perfection, scoring 70 off 42 balls, while Padikkal provided the acceleration with a quickfire 50 off just 27 deliveries. Earlier, Phil Salt gave the innings early momentum with 26, and Jitesh Sharma’s unbeaten 20 off 10 helped push the total past 200. The RR bowlers, despite occasional breakthroughs, were unable to contain the run flow, with Sandeep Sharma picking up two wickets and Hasaranga and Archer chipping in with one each.

In response, RR explosively began their chase, thanks to Yashasvi Jaiswal’s 49 off just 19 balls. Riyan Parag and Dhruv Jurel kept the momentum going in the middle overs, but RCB struck at regular intervals to prevent any one batter from taking the game away. Josh Hazlewood was the standout with the ball, finishing with 4/33, including the key wickets of Jaiswal and Jurel. Krunal Pandya supported well with two scalps, including the RR captain Parag.

 

Riyan Parag (RR Captain)

"I thought we bowled well, but we just didn’t back it up with the bat. At the halfway stage of our chase, we were definitely in the driving seat, and honestly, we’ve only got ourselves to blame. We didn’t show enough intent against the spinners, and that hurt us in key phases. The support staff has given us complete freedom to express ourselves, so the onus is on us, the players, to step up and play with intent. In a tournament like this, even one poor decision can cost you, and that’s what happened tonight. We talk a lot as a group—we’ve discussed scenarios like this before, but unfortunately, we couldn’t execute when it mattered. We were in control, and then we let it slip away. From here on, we have to play for pride. Some fans stand by us, and a lot of people behind the scenes who work incredibly hard for this team.It’s an honour to represent this franchise, and we’ll make sure that the next time we step on the field, we show that pride and fight."
 

Rajat Patidar (RCB Captain)

"This was a much-needed win for us. The wicket played a bit differently than we expected, but full credit to the bowlers—they showed great courage and composure, and won us the game tonight.

The opposition batted well—credit to them for taking it deep. At one point, we knew it was going to be a tight contest, but our focus remained on taking wickets, because that’s how you control the run rate in such games. I usually go with my instincts first, but we have a strong group of leaders in the team. Their support and insights have been extremely valuable and are helping us make the right calls on the field."
 

Josh Hazlewood (Player of the Match)

"First and foremost, it was about sticking to my strengths. On this surface, hard lengths were still tough to hit, so it was all about executing those deliveries consistently. Over the years, I haven’t always had the opportunity to play a lot of T20 cricket, but it's been great getting those chances now. From my time with the Sydney Sixers, Chennai Super Kings, and now RCB, plus experiences with Australia, I’ve gradually picked up what it takes to bowl in this format. Communication is key—we’ve got a great group that shares ideas and bounces plans off one another. Everyone is backing each other, and tonight, it came together well to help us get the result. The bounce at Chinnaswamy has been quite steep throughout the tournament, which suits my bowling style. Full credit to our batters—they did a fantastic job to get us to that total. You’re never completely sure here at Chinnaswamy, but they gave us something to work with, and we backed it up with the ball."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Sunrisers Hyderabad vs Mumbai Indians
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Mumbai Indians Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
This evening in Hyderabad, the Sunrisers Hyderabad take on the surging Mumbai Indians in what could be a defining contest for both sides.SRH, under Pat Cummins, are battling to stay relevant in the playoff race. Their campaign has been punctuated by flashes of brilliance from Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma at the top, but the middle order has lacked stability. Heinrich Klaasen’s power has gone cold, and the team’s finishing ability has come under question. The bowling, though spearheaded by Cummins and Bhuvneshwar Kumar, has failed to defend totals, especially in high-scoring conditions.

In contrast, MI are starting to look like title contenders again. Rohit Sharma’s return to form has added weight at the top, and Suryakumar Yadav is striking the ball with his usual flair. Tilak Varma has quietly become the glue in the middle. Add to that the menace of Jasprit Bumrah with the new ball and at the death, and MI suddenly look sharp, confident, and settled.

The Hyderabad pitch has been a batting paradise this season, with 200-plus scores becoming routine. Dew is expected, which means chasing will be an advantage.

It’s a must-win for SRH. It’s momentum management for MI. Expect a cracker.



IPL Stats at Rajiv Gandhi International since 2024:


Pitch Report – Danny Morrison & Matthew Hayden

It’s scorching hot here in Hyderabad, and we’re back on a pitch that has already hosted a couple of high-scoring encounters this season. The dimensions are slightly skewed—it’s 63 meters to the right, 70 meters to the left, and a long 77 meters down the ground. This is the third time we’re playing on this strip, and the same surface produced all those big totals earlier in the tournament. It’s dry, hard, and has all the makings of a 200-plus wicket—but as always, it will come down to who takes early advantage with the bat or the ball
Danny. While it may not be quite as explosive as that first game against Rajasthan, this is still a terrific batting surface. Both teams have a few skilled swing and seam operators, so the first few overs could be decisive. Once the ball stops moving, expect the batters to take charge. This is a surface that rewards positive intent."



Toss Update: MI won the toss and elected to field first!  

 

???? Toss ???? @mipaltan elected to field against @SunRisers. #MI captain Hardik Pandya and #SRH captain Pat Cummins condemn the gruesome Pahalgam terror attack and pay homage to the victims. #TATAIPL | #SRHvMI pic.twitter.com/qfgPeWpmIF

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 23, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (overs 1-6)
SRH:- 24/1 (4 rpo, 1x4, 1x6) || MI:- 56/1 (9.33 rpo, 6x4, 3x6)

Middle Overs (overs 7-15)
SRH:- 66/4 (7.33 rpo, 7x4, 2x6) || MI:- 81/2 (9 rpo, 9x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (overs 16-20)
SRH:- 53/3 (10.6 rpo, 4x4, 3x6) || MI:- 9/0 (0.4 overs 13.5 rpo, 2x4, 0x6)
 

Mumbai Indians registered a convincing 7-wicket win over Sunrisers Hyderabad in Hyderabad, chasing down 144 with relative ease and continuing their upward momentum in TATA IPL 2025.

Put in to bat, SRH struggled to build momentum after losing early wickets. Trent Boult was instrumental with the ball, striking twice in his opening spell to remove Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma, and returning at the death to dismiss Abhinav Manohar and captain Pat Cummins. Deepak Chahar also applied pressure with a tight 2-wicket haul, conceding just 12 runs in his four overs. Despite the early collapse, Heinrich Klaasen anchored the innings with a well-compiled 71 off 44 balls, supported briefly by Abhinav Manohar (43). However, SRH's inability to string together partnerships meant they finished with a below-par 143/8.

Mumbai’s chase was steady and controlled. Rohit Sharma top-scored with 70 off 46 deliveries, mixing boundaries with smart strike rotation. Will Jacks provided support with 22, while Suryakumar Yadav accelerated the innings late with a rapid 40* off 19 balls to finish the game in the 16th over.
 

Pat Cummins (Sunrisers Hyderabad Captain)

"Yeah, I think Abhinav and Klaasy (Klaasen) did well to get us to a decent total, but we just couldn't build momentum after that. You need one batter to anchor the innings, and unfortunately, we kept losing wickets at regular intervals. We’ve spoken about this before—you can take your time to build an innings, especially if you're a top-order batter. If you use up a few balls early on, you're good enough to catch up later. But starting 0 for 2 makes it really tough. It's all about reading the pitch and adapting accordingly. The contrast from our first game, where we scored 280, to this one, where we were bowled out cheaply—that’s T20 cricket for you. It can swing either way, and it just hasn't clicked for us in the last couple of games. We’ve got a few away games coming up now. So it’s going to be about assessing each wicket, figuring out what's a good score, and planning our innings accordingly. That’s going to be a big part of our discussions moving forward."
 

Hardik Pandya (Mumbai Indians Captain)

"Honestly, it feels great to get the win under our belt. Momentum is key in tournaments like these, and I’m glad the boys are starting to find their rhythm. This team has always had the potential—I've always believed that once everyone starts clicking, we’ll be hard to stop. Today was a great example: Deepak and Boult bowled brilliantly, Rohit gave us a solid start, and Surya finished it off in style.

Captaincy, for me, is all about instincts. I do have plans going into the game, but I also believe in reading the situation and reacting. Chahar bowled really well in the powerplay, so I felt there was no reason to hold him back.

At that point, they were five wickets down, and we wanted to force a mistake. We knew they wouldn’t take too many chances against Santner, so we thought we’d throw something different at them. Puthur is a young guy, and these things happen—it’s all part of learning.

We’ve been focusing on getting better in all departments, and we’ve talked about being smart and clinical as a unit. So far, I’m very satisfied with how things are shaping up."
 

Trent Boult (Player of the Match)

"It’s always nice to contribute to a good team win. This was a big game for us, and to restrict such a quality side to a manageable total on their home ground was very satisfying. It’s the old rule of thumb—just hit the wicket, keep it simple, and try to make the batters play the tougher shots. Deepak did a tremendous job from the other end, bowling four on the trot again and keeping the pressure on. Our goal as a bowling group is to build pressure and force mistakes. It was also great to see a couple of catches stick, which always makes a difference in games like these."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Lucknow Super Giants vs Delhi Capitals
Matchsummary.GroundName: Bharat Ratna Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee Ekana Cricket Stadium
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Delhi Capitals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Tonight, the Ekana Stadium in Lucknow will host a razor-edge IPL 2025 contest between Lucknow Super Giants and Delhi Capitals — two teams deadlocked on 10 points but separated by net run rate. LSG sits fifth; DC, second. But the real narrative runs deeper.

KL Rahul returns to his old den, now wearing DC blue, facing the franchise he once led. The air is thick with anticipation — this isn’t just another game, it’s personal. Earlier this season, LSG lost to DC by just one wicket in a heart-stopper, and they’ll be itching to return the favor.

Rishabh Pant’s side leans on the firepower of Nicholas Pooran, Aiden Markram, and Mitchell Marsh, while their bowling — spearheaded by Avesh Khan and Ravi Bishnoi — has stood tall in crunch moments. DC, on the other hand, finds strength in KL Rahul’s consistency and Mitchell Starc’s early breakthroughs, but Pant’s middling form is starting to raise eyebrows.

The Ekana pitch, no longer the slow-turner of old, now supports totals north of 180. Dew may again make chasing the preferred option.


 

Pitch Report – Deep Dasgupta & Shane Watson

"The average score at this venue is around 190, but if you take this same pitch to another ground with smaller dimensions, you’d easily be looking at 210–215. It’s a large venue—square boundaries measure 72 meters and 60 meters, while down the ground it’s a long 78 meters.

This is a used surface, and it's made of red soil, which traditionally offers good pace and bounce. In the first game here, LSG scored 172, but it was chased down comfortably by Punjab Kings. So this could very well be a ‘win the toss and chase’ kind of pitch."

"It looks like a really nice surface. The hardness of the pitch is the first thing I noticed—it’s clearly had a lot of rolling. When I touched it, I felt like strapping on the pads myself! With red soil, you get natural pace and bounce for the quicks. But there’s also a bit of grip for the spinners, especially early on. This is going to be a true cricket wicket—if you bowl well, you’ll be rewarded. And if you bat well, there are runs to be scored all around the park.
The Lucknow Super Giants’ top three will be eyeing this surface to cash in—they’ll want to make full use of the conditions"


Toss Update: DC Won the Toss and elected to field first!

 

???? Toss ????@DelhiCapitals won the toss and opted to bowl first against @LucknowIPL.

Updates ?? https://t.co/nqIO9mb8Bs#TATAIPL | #LSGvDC pic.twitter.com/cJtkQgliTi

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 22, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Over 1-6)
LSG:- 51/0 (8.5 rpo, 3x4, 3x6) || DC:- 54/1 (9 rpo, 8x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (over 7-15)
LSG:- 67/4 (7.44 rpo, 5x4, 1x6) || DC:- 73/1 (8.11 rpo, 2x4, 5x6)

Death Overs (over 16-20)
LSG:- 41/2 (8.2 rpo, 6x4, 0x6)  || DC:- 34/ (2.5 overs 12 rpo, 1x4, 3x6) 

 

Delhi Capitals chased down 160 in style, powered by KL Rahul’s composed 57 off 42 balls* and a fiery finishing act from skipper Axar Patel (34 off 20)* to seal an 8-wicket win with 13 balls to spare. With this victory, DC showed balance, intent, and ruthlessness.

Put into bat, Lucknow Super Giants rode on Aiden Markram’s fluent 52 (33) and a brisk 36 from Ayush Badoni. But from 87/0, they lost 6 wickets for just 72 runs, derailing their momentum. Mukesh Kumar starred with 4/33, including the key scalps of Marsh, Pant, and Badoni in the death.

In response, Abishek Porel provided a punchy start with 51 off 36, while Karun Nair chipped in with a cameo. Once Porel fell, it was the KL-Axar show — controlled, classy, and calmly finished.

Markram picked up two wickets with the ball, but DC’s top-order composure and LSG’s bowling struggles made the difference.



 

Rishabh Pant (Lucknow Super Giants Captain)

"Yes, definitely. We knew we were around 20 runs short today. In Lucknow, the toss plays a huge role—whoever bowls first tends to get a lot of assistance from the surface. We needed to stay in the game longer, but we couldn’t quite get away with the bat when it mattered. That’s the nature of this venue. In second innings, the pitch gets increasingly difficult to bat on. But that’s how it goes—we’re not here to make excuses. As a team, we’re focused on learning and improving.

[On not using Mayank as Impact Sub]
Mayank just came back from the NCA, and we’re trying to find the right role and place for him in the XI.

[On batting lower down the order]
The idea was to capitalize early. We sent Samad up the order for that reason. Then Miller came in, but we got a bit stuck in the middle. It’s something we’ll reflect on. We’ve got to keep finding ways to adapt and improve.

[Looking ahead]
We haven’t thought about the next game yet. Right now, it’s about regrouping, resetting, and going into the next match with a fresh mindset."
 

Axar Patel (Delhi Capitals Captain)

"It was an up-and-down game. We didn’t pick up wickets during the powerplay, but we did well to restrict the total and stay in the contest. Throughout the innings, we were focused on breaking partnerships, and every bowler stepped up to pull things back brilliantly.

[On his own bowling]
As captain, I chose to start with the first over myself. I’ve been managing a finger injury, which is why I hadn’t bowled much recently. But I’m feeling a lot better now, and I bowled again in the powerplay. When you’re in good rhythm, it becomes easier to bowl four overs on the trot.

[Tactical decisions]
I kept an eye on match-ups and how the pitch was behaving. I used pacers strategically, especially considering the boundary dimensions. When Pooran came to bat, I remembered Starc dismissing him in the last game, so I brought him on straightaway to try and repeat that matchup.

[Batting at No. 4]
I bat according to the situation and try to take on bowlers based on my strengths. I have a clear mindset—when I promote myself, I already know who I want to target on the opposition side. It’s worked well for me so far, and I hope that continues.

[Areas for improvement]
Fielding is one area we really need to improve. You can have an off day with bat or ball, but we’ve been dropping catches consistently, and that hurts—especially when bowlers are executing plans well. Even with those lapses, we did well to keep them under 160, which was a solid result under the circumstances."
 

Mukesh Kumar (Player of the Match)

"I’m feeling really good tonight. I enjoyed bowling on this wicket—it suited my style well. When I came on to bowl my second over, I had a quick chat with Chameera and Starc, and they mentioned that the ball was stopping off the surface a bit. That helped me plan my approach. I focused on hitting the right lengths and mixing in my variations effectively. I always like to stay in conversation with the skipper—he gave me clear instructions on maintaining a consistent length and using slower deliveries at the right moments. I stuck to that plan, and it worked.

[On his favourite wicket]
For me, the most important wicket was Mitchell Marsh. He was set in the middle and could have done serious damage later on. Getting him out at that stage was crucial for our team.

[On his overall performance]
I’m genuinely happy with how I performed today. I’ve been looking for a performance like this all season—it wasn’t quite coming together in the first half, but I’m glad it clicked tonight. I just want to carry this momentum forward and keep contributing for the team."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Kolkata Knight Riders vs Gujarat Titans
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Kolkata Knight Riders Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, buckle up—because Eden Gardens is about to witness a sizzler! In one corner, we have the Gujarat Titans—confident, clinical, and cruising at the top. In the other, Kolkata Knight Riders—a team with a point to prove, bruised but still dangerous, fighting for survival in the league. This isn’t just a game—it’s a battle of belief, bottle, and brilliance.

KKR, led by Ajinkya Rahane, have blown hot and cold this season. Rahane’s experience has anchored their innings repeatedly, but it’s high time the likes of De Kock, Russell, and Narine brought their A-game to the party. With spin-friendly conditions, Varun Chakaravarthy and Narine could be KKR’s trump cards—if they can crack GT’s power-packed top order.

Speaking of GT—what a juggernaut they’ve been! The Englishman Jos Buttler is in red-hot form, smashing an unbeaten 97 in the last match. Sai Sudharsan is piling up runs for fun and breathing down the neck of the Orange Cap leader. And Prasidh Krishna? Fourteen wickets and counting—he’s been venomous with the new ball and brutal at the death.

But here’s the deal—Eden Gardens is no stranger to drama. Two pitches have been prepared; the buzz is that one favors seamers and the other slow turners. The toss could be worth its weight in gold, especially with dew expected later in the night.

Pitch Report |  Nick Knight & Eoin Morgan 

"The defending champions are back at their fortress, and they’ll be desperate to pick up two crucial points tonight. Let’s talk about the pitch. This is a very Eden Gardens-like pitch. There’s grass covering, especially around the good length and short-of-a-length areas. That tells us we can expect a consistent bounce and decent pace tonight .From what we’ve seen in past games here, early swing is often a factor, particularly in the first couple of overs. So bowlers will want to make full use of that upfront. Now, if there wasn’t as much grass, we might’ve expected a bit of turn—but not tonight. The surface won’t offer much assistance for spinners, so they’ll be in for a challenge.All signs point to a high-scoring contest, but there could be movement with the new ball early on. The key for KKR is early wickets. They have to utilize the swing while it lasts. Guys like Harshit Rana and Vaibhav Arora must pitch it up, just as they did against SRH, and look for movement.GT’s top three have been batting deep into the powerplay. If KKR can disrupt that rhythm early, it’ll put pressure on GT’s middle order, who haven’t been tested as much. That could change the complexion of the game."



TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
 

???? Toss ????@KKRiders won the toss and elected to bowl against @gujarat_titans in Kolkata.

Updates ?? https://t.co/TwaiwD5D6n#TATAIPL | #KKRvGT pic.twitter.com/Rof135hqli

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 21, 2025

GT:- 45/0 (7.5 rpo, 6x4, 0x6) || KKR:- 45/2 (7.5 rpo, 6x4, 1x6)

In a poetic twist of fate, Match 39 of the season ended with a 39-run win for Gujarat Titans, who now storm to the top of the points table with a statement performance over Kolkata Knight Riders.

Batting first, GT were anchored by a sublime knock from captain Shubman Gill, who struck a classy 90 off 55 balls, blending elegance with authority. Sai Sudharsan (52 off 36) laid the platform early, and a late blitz from Jos Buttler (41 off 23)* ensured a towering total of 198/3.

In response, KKR faltered early with Siraj removing Gurbaz in the opening over. Ajinkya Rahane’s fighting fifty kept hopes flickering, but the GT bowling unit turned the screws. Rashid Khan outfoxed Russell for the sixth time in T20s, while Prasidh Krishna’s double blow in the 16th over crushed the chase.

Angkrish Raghuvanshi (27 off 13)* added some late spark, but it wasn’t enough as KKR limped to 159/8.

A clinical performance in every department, this win wasn’t just dominant — it was symbolic. Match 39. Win by 39. Gujarat on top. 

 

Ajinkya Rahane | KKR Captain:
"To be honest, I felt 199 was a chaseable target. We did well to come back into the game with the ball. But while chasing a total like that, you need a strong start, and that’s where we’ve been struggling throughout this tournament.The pitch was a little on the slower side. When we were bowling, our goal was to keep them below 200, which we managed. But then, in the middle overs, we couldn’t quite string together the partnerships we needed. That’s another phase where we need to improve.I have no complaints with our bowlers—they’ve been executing really well.Fielding is one area we can control better as a team. If we can save even 15–20 runs in the field, it could make a massive difference in a game like this. Staying switched on throughout the innings is crucial, and the boys are working hard on that.This format is all about being brave. We can’t dwell too much on what’s happened in previous games. Whether we’re winning or not, we have to keep looking for small improvements—even 1% better can make an impact.As a batting unit, I tell the guys it’s okay to get out trying to hit a boundary. You’ve got to show intent and play fearlessly. We have some quality batters, especially in the middle overs, and I fully back them to step up.Great to see him doing well. He’s been batting really well, and today we decided to push the other batters to help bring the required run rate under control. The intent was right—we just need to execute a bit better moving forward." 

 

Shubman Gill | GT Captain & Player of the Match:

"Very pleased with the result—two wins in a row is always a great feeling.Our focus is simple: play our best cricket and maximize scoring opportunities based on the pitch conditions. We talk more about how we can approach each surface rather than fixating on results. The idea is always to take the game deep and give ourselves the best chance to post or chase down a strong total.We were ahead in the game for most of it—but as we know, closing games is a different challenge. Top teams know how to finish the job, and that’s what I was expressing—those were the emotions of wanting to close it properly.It’s hard to play a perfect T20 game. There will always be a few things you wish you did better. For example, I feel we could’ve scored 10 more runs if I had stayed on. We also made a couple of unforced errors in key moments.But that’s the beauty of the format—even when you’re not playing perfectly, the best teams find a way to win, and that’s what we’re doing well as a group."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Mumbai Indians vs Chennai Super Kings
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Mumbai Indians Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The El Clásico of the IPL is back! Five-time champions Mumbai Indians (MI) and Chennai Super Kings (CSK) collide at the Wankhede Stadium tonight in a high-voltage showdown dripping with history, pride, and playoff implications. MI, riding a resurgent wave with three consecutive wins,seek revenge for their earlier loss to CSK, while the struggling Yellow Army—anchored by the legendary MS Dhoni—fights to keep their faint playoff hopes alive after snapping a five-match losing streak.  

The numbers narrate a fierce rivalry: MI lead 20-18 in 38 clashes,but CSK have dominated recent meetings with five wins in six games. Wankhede’s flat deck and dew-laden evenings favor chasing sides, setting the stage for tactical fireworks. MI’s Suryakumar Yadav, the *360-degree maverick,faces a spin test against CSK’s Afghan sensation Noor Ahmad, while Hardik Pandya’s all-round flair and Jasprit Bumrah’s death-overs mastery add intrigue. For CSK, Dhoni’s finishing aura—evident in his recent 11-ball 26—and Rachin Ravindra’s resurgence loom large.  

With clear skies and a 184-run average first-innings score in the last two years, expect a run-fest under lights.The toss could be pivotal: two of three Wankhede games this season were won by chasers.

VENUE STATS:-

PITCH REPORT:-

Simon Doull:- "We're back on Pitch No. 8, and the dimensions are quite striking — just 60 meters on one side with a slight breeze, 66 meters towards the east, and 73 meters straight down the ground. The last game on this surface saw a mammoth 430 runs scored, and there’s every chance we’re in for another run-fest. This pitch appears a bit drier than what we saw on Thursday night. The center has a consistent grass covering, but the areas around a fuller length are noticeably more parched, which could bring a bit more spin into play. There was a hint of tackiness for the side batting first last time, but that doesn't seem to be the case today. This looks like a true, solid batting surface. Given the typical dew factor that sets in during the evening, both teams are likely to prefer chasing. It’s a surface made for runs — putting a total on the board may work, but with dew coming in, batting second might just be the easier path. Expect a high-scoring affair."

TOSS:-

TOSS HAS FAVOURED THE HOME TEAM AND MUMBAI WILL FIELD FIRST!
 

???? Toss ????@mipaltan won the toss and elected to bowl against @ChennaiIPL in Mumbai.

Updates ? https://t.co/v2k7Y5sIdi#TATAIPL | #MIvCSK pic.twitter.com/o62WJevedv

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 20, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
CSK:- 48/1 (8 rpo, 3x4, 2x6) || MI:- 62/0 (10.33 rpo, 5x4, 4x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
CSK:- 70/2 (7.77 rpo, 5x4, 2x6) || MI:- 95/1 (10.55 rpo, 8x4, 5x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20)
CSK:- 58/2 (11.6 rpo, 4x4, 4x6)  || MI:- 20/0 (0.4 overs, 30 rpo, 0x4, 3x6)
 

Under the electric lights of Wankhede, Mumbai Indians delivered a clinical chase to outclass Chennai Super Kings by nine wickets in a one-sided IPL 2025 fixture.

Put into bat, CSK posted 176/5 on a belter of a surface. The innings got a push from young Ayush Mhatre, who impressed on debut with a blistering 32 off just 15 balls, while Shivam Dube (50 off 32) and Ravindra Jadeja (53* off 35) combined to anchor the middle and late overs. However, MI pulled things back with Bumrah’s precise death bowling (2/25), keeping the visitors from breaching 180.

Chasing 177, Mumbai started with a bang. Ryan Rickelton played the aggressor early, but once he fell for 24, it was the Rohit-Suryakumar show all the way. Rohit Sharma turned back the clock with a classy 76* off 45 balls, mixing power and placement with ease. At the other end, Suryakumar Yadav was in his element – reverse sweeps, lofts, flicks – all on display in his stunning 68* off just 30.

The duo added 114 runs in just 51 balls, completely deflating CSK’s bowling attack, which lacked venom on the night. Pathirana and Noor Ahmad came in for some serious punishment, going at over 12 an over.
 

MS Dhoni (Chennai Super Kings Captain)

"I think we were quite below par today. We knew the dew would come into play, so we planned to create pressure during the middle overs. In hindsight, we probably should have accelerated earlier, especially before Bumrah came into the attack. He’s one of the best death bowlers in the world, and once he started his spell, it became much harder to score freely. 175 was never a par score on this ground—we needed to push harder and carry more momentum into the back end of our innings.

[On Ayush Mhatre]
As a youngster, I thought he batted well tonight. His shot selection was impressive, and right from the start, he played with positive intent. We haven’t seen much of him yet, but it was a very promising knock. The dew became a factor in the second innings. While the ball did grip a little, they played spin exceptionally well. Especially Surya—he’s a fantastic player of spin, and once the ball came nicely onto the bat, it was always going to be tough for us.

[On the approach going forward]
We need to be practical, not emotional. To be successful, you have to play good, smart cricket. We also dropped a few catches today, which hurt us.It’s important to take it one game at a time. Even if we lose a couple, the goal is to find the right combination moving forward. We don’t want to make too many changes. Of course, we’re aiming to make the playoffs. But if we don’t, our focus will shift to building a settled XI and coming back stronger next season."
 

Hardik Pandya (Mumbai Indians Captain)

"The way we’re approaching the game right now, we knew it was going to be a high-scoring contest, and we backed ourselves by playing the percentages.No need to worry about Rohit's form—he’s a big-match player. When he clicks, the opposition is usually out of the game. And tonight, the way Surya batted was exceptional. That partnership between them truly took the game away. We’re keeping things simple—sticking to the basics, playing smart cricket, and executing the plans we’ve committed to. In hindsight, yes, we might’ve been able to sneak in an over or two differently, but we were always playing catch-up. At the end of the day, a total around 175–180 was below par on this surface.I don’t think we were too far away from a win—we just needed to put all the pieces together. That’s something we’ll keep working on moving forward."
 

Rohit Sharma (Player of the Match)

[On fans in yellow jerseys cheering for him]
That’s the beauty of Wankhede. The fans here love the game, and that’s what makes this place so special. Whether you're wearing yellow or blue, when people appreciate good cricket, it’s heartwarming. Today was one of those games.

Having been around for a long time, it's easy to fall into self-doubt or try to overcomplicate things. For me, the key was to go back to basics, keep it simple, and maintain a clear mindset. That’s how I like to plan my innings—hold my shape, extend through the line, and when the ball is in my zone, I know what I have to do.We had a chat about the batting order—whether to come in immediately after fielding. Honestly, two or three overs don’t make a huge difference, and even if I haven’t been on the field for long, I’m happy to walk straight in if that’s what the team needs. That upper stand feels far away when you’re in the middle, but I loved being out there today. For me, staying in the middle and finishing games is what gives me the most satisfaction. We’re peaking at the right time, three wins in a row now, and the momentum is building.On a personal note, it’s a huge honour. I’ve said this before—as a kid growing up, there was a time when we weren’t even allowed inside this stadium. And now, to have played all my cricket here—it means everything. Whenever that 'Rohit Sharma at Wankhede' chant goes up, honestly... I still don’t know how to react. It’s pure emotion.

Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
In a swift turnaround, the Punjab Kings (PBKS) are set to host the Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) in Match 37 of the TATA IPL 2025 at the Maharaja Yadavindra Singh International Stadium in Mullanpur, just 40 hours after their previous encounter. In that rain-shortened 14-over match, PBKS secured a five-wicket victory, handing RCB their third consecutive home defeat.

RCB, under the leadership of Rajat Patidar, have exhibited contrasting performances this season. While they boast an impeccable away record with four wins, their home form has been lackluster. The batting trio of Virat Kohli, Patidar, and Phil Salt has been instrumental in their victories, but the team will be eager to bounce back from their recent loss. 

On the other hand, PBKS, captained by Shreyas Iyer, have been in impressive form, winning five out of their last seven matches. Their bowling unit, led by Yuzvendra Chahal and Arshdeep Singh, has been particularly effective, especially in defending low totals. The team will aim to continue their winning momentum and solidify their position in the top half of the table. 

 As the two teams prepare for this crucial encounter, the question remains: Will RCB maintain their flawless away record, or will PBKS continue their ascent in the standings?

VENUE STATS:-

PITCH REPORT:-

Varun Aaron: "The boundaries here are 63 meters on one side, 70 meters on the other, and 76 meters straight down the ground. There's a breeze flowing along the ground, which could play a role in the game. The wicket looks solid and in great condition. It’s pitch number three, and the last match here, between PBKS and CSK, saw a massive total of 420 runs. While the pitch has a few cracks, the grass covering should help keep it together. Overall, it seems like a pitch where the ball will come onto the bat nicely."

TOSS:-

RAJAT CALLS RIGHT AT THE TOSS AND RCB ELECT TO FIELD FIRST! 
 

???? Toss ????@RCBTweets won the toss and elected to bowl against @PunjabKingsIPL in Match 37.

Updates ?? https://t.co/6htVhCbltp#TATAIPL | #PBKSvRCB pic.twitter.com/gg5M40bjrg

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 20, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
PBKS:- 62/1 (10.33 rpo, 9x4, 2x6) || RCB:- 54/1 (9 rpo, 7x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
PBKS:- 57/5 (6.33 rpo, 3x4, 1x6) || RCB:- 68/1 (7.7 rpo, 4x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20)
PBKS:- 38/0 (7.6 rpo, 0x4, 2x6) || RCB:- 37/1 (9.65 rpo, 2x4, 2x6)

 

 

On a night where class met composure, Royal Challengers Bengaluru flexed their muscles with a commanding seven-wicket win over Punjab Kings in Match 37 of the TATA IPL 2025.

Set a target of 158, RCB’s chase was anchored by none other than Virat Kohli, who played the sheet anchor’s role to perfection with an unbeaten 73 off 54 balls. Devdutt Padikkal, aggressive from the get-go, smashed a blistering 61 off just 35 balls, peppering the boundaries with flair. Their 103-run stand for the second wicket shut the door on any PBKS hopes early.

Earlier, Punjab Kings started brightly with the bat. Openers Priyansh Arya (22 off 15) and Prabhsimran Singh (33 off 17) gave them a turbocharged start. But Krunal Pandya's crafty spell (2/25) and Suyash Sharma’s guile (2/26) put the brakes on their innings. Despite a late push from Shashank Singh (31*) and Marco Jansen (25*), PBKS could only muster 157/6.

RCB’s bowlers kept things tight, and their batters chased it down with 7 balls to spare. Kohli’s form continues to shine, and with five wins in five away games, Bengaluru are turning into road warriors.


 

Shreyas Iyer (Punjab Kings Captain)

"The body feels good—just a minor niggle. I should be fine after this game.

Looking at our batting, I feel most of our players are looking to go big right from ball one. We're not assessing the conditions well enough. In these afternoon games, the pitch tends to slow down considerably, and we haven’t been able to post totals that we can defend.

We’ve been getting decent starts, but we’re not capitalizing during the middle phase. That’s where we’re falling short.

Credit to Virat and his team—they played tremendously well. It was a comprehensive win for them.

Yes, adapting to the surface is something we talk about regularly. Once the ball gets older, it stops skidding and becomes harder to play strokes. We have naturally positive players, but the middle-order needs to step up and ensure we put up defendable totals for our bowlers.

Personally, I feel I’m in a great headspace. I don’t want to make excuses or play with fear. We need to be free-flowing, not dwell on past performances, and make the most of the starts we’ve been getting.

We now have a six-day break, which comes at a good time. We’ve been on the road for a while and it does take a toll on the body. It’s important that we recover well and come back in top shape for the next game."
 

Rajat Patidar (Royal Challengers Bengaluru Captain)

"Yes, full credit goes to the bowlers—the way they executed the plans and how each one contributed at different stages was just brilliant to watch.

The message was simple: bowl tight lines, stick to the stumps, and keep it disciplined. That was our focus going into the match.

We had a chat at the team hotel last night, especially about fielding strategies for the second half. There was clear intent behind those discussions, and credit to the boys—they followed through and put in the effort. It showed out there.

Looking ahead, first of all, I’ll need to win the toss (smiles). But more importantly, we’ll focus on playing good cricket and look to rectify the areas we still need to improve. That’s the goal moving forward."
 

Virat Kohli (Player of the Match)

"Yeah, this was an important game for us. Moving from 8 to 10 points makes a huge difference in the qualification race. We’ve set ourselves up nicely now, and the way we’ve played, especially away from home, has been fantastic. The mindset remains simple—get those 2 points for the team.

There have been times when I’ve wanted to accelerate more, but I feel my role shifts depending on the situation—especially if Salt doesn’t get going. Then it becomes important for me to anchor the innings.

Honestly, I don’t know why I got this award today—Dev really created the impact that shifted the game. I just used my experience to close it out. I enjoy playing that role—holding one end, assessing the conditions, and accelerating when needed.

It’s tempting to go hard every game, but we have to read the conditions. We took learnings from the first two games. The last one was shortened, so we had to go after it. But in general, understanding the surface and adapting is key.

When you’re at a new venue, one good partnership is often enough in T20s. For me, it’s about knowing the strengths of others, giving them the freedom to express themselves, and making sure one end is held together.

Credit to the auction planning—we got the team we wanted. Jitesh, Salt, and Dev have been playing outstanding roles, and the addition of Romario has boosted our lower-order firepower, something we lacked in recent seasons.

This season, even if the top order fails, we know there are players who can still take the game deep. When you have that kind of depth and belief, your chances of winning go up significantly."

Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the Sawai Mansingh Stadium in Jaipur, where the Rajasthan Royals  are set to clash with the Lucknow Super Giants  in what promises to be a high-octane encounter! The Royals, currently languishing at eighth on the points table with just two wins from seven matches, are desperate to turn their fortunes around. Their campaign has been marred by inconsistency, and the fitness of captain Sanju Samson remains a concern after he suffered a side strain in the previous game.On the other hand, the Super Giants are sitting comfortably at fifth, boasting four wins from seven outings. Their batting lineup has been firing on all cylinders, with Nicholas Pooran leading the charge with 357 runs. The return of pace sensation Mayank Yadav from injury could further bolster their bowling attack. The pitch at Jaipur has been a balanced one, offering something for both batters and bowlers. With conditions ideal for a thrilling contest, buckle up for a rollercoaster ride of IPL action as the Royals and Super Giants battle it out under the lights in Jaipur!



IPL Stats at Sawai Mansingh Since 2024:
 
 

Pitch Report – Simon Katich & Shane Watson

"We’re standing on Pitch Number 5, and at first glance, there’s a nice, even coverage of grass across the surface. That should provide good pace and bounce for the quicks, especially early on.There are a few bare patches in certain areas, and given the hot and dry conditions throughout the day, the surface could break up a bit as the game progresses.Rajasthan Royals have an excellent record here—a win percentage just under 64%. Two games were played on this very pitch last season, and RR won both, with scores hovering around the 185-run mark.It’s all set up for a real shootout tonight. RR are coming off three consecutive losses, so there’s no doubt they’ll be desperate to bounce back.This venue has been good to them in the past, and with the pitch offering something for both batters and pacers, it’s the perfect setting for a high-octane clash. Tonight’s game could be season-defining for them." 


 

TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
 

???? Toss ????@LucknowIPL won the toss and elected to bat against @rajasthanroyals

Updates ?? https://t.co/02MS6IBY0N#TATAIPL | #RRvLSG pic.twitter.com/eNRkH8djGZ

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 19, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1- 6 Overs) :
LSG - 46/2 (7.66 rpo, 7x4, 0x6)  ll  RR - 61/0 (10.16 rpo, 3x4, 6x6)

Middle Overs (7- 15 Overs) :
LSG - 75/1 (8.33 rpo, 3x4, 3x6)  ll  RR - 74/2 (8.22 rpo, 5x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (16- 20 Overs) :
LSG - 59/1 (11.8 rpo, 2x4, 4x6) ll  RR - 43/3 (8.6 rpo, 4x4, 1x6) 
 

In a match that had everything – big knocks, late twists, and final-over drama – Lucknow Super Giants pulled off a thrilling 2-run win over Rajasthan Royals in Jaipur. Batting first, LSG rode on solid knocks from Aiden Markram (66 off 45) and Ayush Badoni (50 off 34), who stitched a crucial 76-run partnership to steady the innings. Abdul Samad’s late cameo – 30* off 10 balls – lifted the visitors to a competitive 180/5.

Rajasthan Royals came out firing with Yashasvi Jaiswal anchoring the chase with a sublime 74 off 52. Debutant Vaibhav Suryavanshi added fireworks of his own with a fearless 34, while Riyan Parag chipped in with 39. But the chase unraveled at the death as Avesh Khan produced a sensational final over, defending 9 runs with ice in his veins.

Despite a dropped catch and a missed run-out chance, Avesh's yorkers proved too good under pressure. He finished with 3/37, sealing the win as Royals fell just short at 178/5.

It was a match that showcased the nerves of steel required in crunch moments – and Avesh Khan walked away with all the applause. 

 

Riyan Parag | Rajasthan Royals Captain:
"It’s honestly really hard to process everything right now. Emotions are all over the place.I don’t exactly know where we went wrong—we were in the game right up until the 19th over. After that, things just slipped away.Someone has to take responsibility, and I’m willing to own it. I’ll put my hand up—it was on me. We should have finished the game.To win matches consistently, we need to collectively play all 40 overs as a unit. Only then can we expect results to go our way.I thought we bowled really well for most of the innings. The final over was just unfortunate. I genuinely believed we could restrict them to 165–170, but that last over hurt us.Sandy bhai (Sandeep Sharma) had an off day—it happens—and Abdul Samad batted brilliantly. Those 15–20 extra runs made a big difference.The pitch was perfect today. We knew exactly how it would play. No excuses—we have to blame ourselves for not executing when it mattered." 

 

Rishabh Pant | Lucknow Super Giants Captain:
Wins like these are special—they build character and resilience. It was an amazing win, and I truly believe this is the kind of performance that takes us to the next level as a team.These are the positives we always talk about in the dressing room, and it’s great to see them play out on the field. We’re definitely moving in the right direction.Full credit to the bowlers for holding their nerve—especially in high-pressure moments. It’s never easy when you’re chasing the game, but they showed composure.Avesh was fantastic—the way he executed under pressure, particularly in the final over, was outstanding.The message was simple: take your time, stay clear in your mind, and focus on executing one ball at a time. That approach worked for us tonight.For now, I’m just enjoying the win—it was a much-needed one, and hopefully, there’s more to come."
 

Avesh Khan | Player of the Match:
The hand’s okay now. For a moment, I thought it was broken—I got hit right where I was holding my phone and literally saw stars. Didn’t even get the time to celebrate properly!I don’t want to be the next Mitchell Starc—I want to be the best version of Avesh Khan. My focus is on bowling with clarity and executing my plans with precision.I don’t pay too much attention to the scoreboard while bowling. My goal is to back my execution. The idea, especially in the final over, was to restrict boundaries in the first three balls to build pressure on the batters.When the ball went up, I saw David Miller and thought, ‘He’s got it.’ Saving six runs is critical—especially on grounds like this, where even mistimed shots can fly to the boundary.We were mostly discussing field placements—especially who should go out to the deep. I’m learning to understand my own bowling patterns, which helps in making those decisions.I always put the team first. Tonight, I just wanted to win the game for us. We’ve got six more matches to go, and I’ll give my all to help us win those too—with more performances like this one."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Gujarat Titans vs Delhi Capitals
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Gujarat Titans Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, hold onto your seats – it’s time for a scorcher in the desert! As the mercury rises to a blistering 38°C in Ahmedabad, so does the temperature in the IPL 2025 points table. The Gujarat Titans   take on the Delhi Capitals  in a top-of-the-table showdown that promises edge-of-the-seat action from ball one!

Gujarat, led by the ever-elegant Shubman Gill, are coming off a wake-up call against Lucknow and will be desperate to roar back. Expect fireworks from the top order – Gill, Sai Sudharsan, and the ever-explosive Jos Buttler. But it’s the pace battery of Siraj and Prasidh Krishna that’s been turning heads – raw pace, red-hot rhythm, and eyes firmly set on that Purple Cap.

Meanwhile, Delhi are riding a high. Captain Axar Patel has quietly marshaled his troops with precision. KL Rahul has been the calm in the storm at the top, while Tristan Stubbs is doing what Stubbs does best – lighting up the stage with fearless batting. Add the menace of Starc and the mystery of Kuldeep to the mix, and you’ve got a bowling attack that’s got teeth.

The Narendra Modi Stadium pitch? A belter! Expect runs galore, sixes raining, and bowlers praying for mercy. This isn’t just a match, folks – this is a battle for supremacy. Expect drama, expect adrenaline, expect nothing short of magic. Buckle up – GT vs DC is about to blow the roof off!





IPL Stats at Narendra Modi Stadium Since 2024:

 

Pitch Report – Daren Ganga & Michael Clarke

"It’s hot and steamy here in Ahmedabad as we gear up for another exciting clash. We’re playing on Pitch Number 6, and in terms of dimensions—it’s 64 meters to my right, 69 meters to the left, and 73 meters straight down the ground.Watch out for those shorter pockets behind square—they could play a big role today.This very pitch has hosted all three matches this season, and the average first innings score is a whopping 219. What’s more, all teams batting first have gone on to win.I reckon we’re going to see much of the same again today. This is a beautiful-looking wicket—there’s a nice, even covering of grass, but it’s also rock hard.The light roller’s been used, and it looks like an absolute belter of a batting pitch. I fully expect the captain winning the toss to bat first, put runs on the board, and try to build pressure while defendingThe pitch has been a standout this season—true bounce, consistent pace—and it’s likely to remain the same right through the match.Since it's a day game, dew won’t be a factor either. All signs point to another high-scoring contest."

On a high-octane night in Ahmedabad, Jos Buttler produced a masterclass for the ages, powering Gujarat Titans to a record 204-run chase against Delhi Capitals in Match 47 of IPL 2025. Buttler remained unbeaten on 97 off 54 balls, with Rahul Tewatia applying the final touches in typical ice-cold style.

DC were off to a flier, thanks to Abishek Porel’s fiery 18 (9) and KL Rahul’s explosive 28 (14). Karun Nair continued his resurgence with a quick 31, while skipper Axar Patel held the innings together with 39 (32). A late blitz from Ashutosh Sharma (37 off 19) catapulted DC past the 200-mark.

But the star with the ball was Prasidh Krishna, who continued his golden season, finishing with 4/41, including the key wickets of Rahul, Axar, and Nair. Despite a few costly overs from Siraj and Arshad, GT managed to restrict the death overs just enough to stay in the hunt.

Chasing 204, GT lost Gill early to a direct hit from Nair, but the innings belonged to Jos Buttler. He went from elegant to explosive, mixing finesse with firepower as he clobbered 11 fours and 4 sixes en route to an unbeaten 97 (54).

Sai Sudharsan (36 off 21) gave the early momentum, while Sherfane Rutherford (43 off 34) matched Buttler shot for shot in the middle overs. DC’s bowlers had no answers under pressure, with Starc leaking 49 runs in just 3.2 overs.

Just when things looked tight, Tewatia walked in and did what Tewatia does best — a six and a four off Starc in the final over to seal the deal.

 
 

Axar Patel | Delhi Capitals Captain:
"I think we were 10–15 runs short, and in the end, that made the difference.Every time we tried to accelerate, we lost wickets and couldn’t build lasting partnerships. We needed to find a few more boundaries.I thought our bowlers did a really good job, but some missed chances in the field—dropped catches and small lapses—also cost us.No need to overthink it. These were small moments—just one or two hits or tighter fielding decisions—and we could’ve turned it around. We just need to avoid repeating those mistakes."
 

Shubman Gill | Gujarat Titans Captain:
"The way we pulled things back with the ball was impressive. At one stage, it looked like they’d get 230–240, but our bowlers stepped up and brought us back into the contest.We’ve done well chasing throughout the tournament. Even in the last game chasing 245, we stayed in the game right till the end.With Axar still at the crease, we chose to stick with pace to keep things tight and avoid giving momentum away.Personally, it was a disappointing way to get out, but there are plenty of matches left, and I’ll look to bounce back.The way Buttler and Rutherford batted was incredible. They rotated strike well and picked the right moments to attack. Their execution was spot on.We’ve got back-to-back matches now—today and then at Eden. If we can win both, we’ll be in a strong position on the points table."
 

Jos Buttler | Player of the Match:
"Really pleased to come away with two points and a win. It was a beautiful pitch to bat on, and we picked our moments well, building good partnerships along the way.The heat was intense—it really hits you out there. You don’t realize how draining it can be, but it’s part of the challenge. You've got to stay fit and perform under pressure, even in tough conditions.I’ve not kept that well in the last six games, so I was eager to improve. Felt nice to take that catch—it gives you a bit of confidence.It’s been a pleasure. He’s got serious power—can hit sixes from nowhere. That over against Mohit, where he hit two sixes, swung momentum our way.
Of course, you want to get a century, but the main thing is winning the game. I had my chances but couldn’t convert. I told Rahul not to worry about me—we needed to finish the match. He’s done it many times before, calm under pressure and finding the fence from ball one."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Royal Challengers Bengaluru vs Punjab Kings
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Punjab Kings Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the cauldron of cricketing drama, the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bengaluru, where tonight, under the dazzling lights, Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) lock horns with Punjab Kings (PBKS) in Match 34 of IPL 2025! Both teams stride into this contest with identical records—four wins from six outings—making this clash pivotal in the race for playoff supremacy.RCB, despite their formidable lineup, have yet to taste victory at home this season. But with Virat Kohli leading the charge and the likes of Phil Salt and Rajat Patidar in the mix, the home crowd will be hoping for a change in fortunes. Conversely, PBKS arrive with momentum, having pulled off a sensational defense of a low total against KKR. Their bowling arsenal, featuring Arshdeep Singh and Yuzvendra Chahal, will be keen to exploit any chinks in RCB's armor. The pitch at Chinnaswamy is a batter's paradise, promising a run-fest. But with the weather playing coy, a few rain interruptions could spice things up.So, buckle up, folks! As the sun sets and the floodlights blaze, expect a rollercoaster of emotions, big hits, and nail-biting moments.

19:00 IST Toss delayed due to rain

RCB:- 48/2 (12 rpo, 5x4, 3x6) || PBKS:- 33/1 in 2.1 overs (15.23 rpo, 2x4, 3x6) 
 

After persistent rain forced a delayed start, turning this much-anticipated clash into a 14-over slugfest, fans were treated to a rollercoaster at the M Chinnaswamy Stadium. What began as a power-hitting showcase from Tim David became a redemption story for Nehal Wadhera as Punjab Kings defeated Royal Challengers Bengaluru by 5 wickets, registering back-to-back wins in the 2025 IPL season.

Toss eventually took place at 9:30 PM IST, with the game reduced to 14 overs a side. The pitch was tacky, and the powerplay just four overs. Every ball was crucial. RCB were put in to bat and that’s where the troubles began.

RCB’s innings never got going. Phil Salt, Virat Kohli, and Liam Livingstone all fell cheaply as Arshdeep Singh and Marco Jansen wrecked the top-order. Skipper Rajat Patidar tried to counter but fell to Chahal after a brief 23. From there, RCB slid to 42/7, and it looked like a sub-80 score was on the cards.

In what turned out to be a rescue act of the highest quality, David smashed an unbeaten 50 off just 26 balls, peppering with five boundaries and three sixes. He clobbered Harpreet Brar in the final over, taking RCB to a competitive 95/9 in 14 overs — a score that once seemed out of reach.

PBKS started briskly with Priyansh Arya and Prabhsimran Singh, but Hazlewood and Bhuvi struck in the powerplay to dent their momentum. Inglis and skipper Shreyas Iyer also departed in quick succession, leaving Punjab reeling at 53/4.

But Nehal Wadhera, cool as ever, absorbed the pressure and counter-punched in style. He stitched together vital runs with calculated aggression, hitting 33* off 19 balls, including a six and a four. Marcus Stoinis finished it off with a towering six, as Punjab chased down the target in 12.1 overs, clinching the game with 11 balls to spare.



 

Rajat Patidar | Royal Challengers Bengaluru Captain
"Early on, the pitch was sticking a bit and felt two-paced. We could’ve certainly done a lot better as a batting unit.When you’re batting first, partnerships become crucial. Unfortunately, we kept losing wickets at regular intervals and couldn’t build any momentum.It was a conditions-based decision—we had to make that change to adapt.Honestly, it wasn’t a bad wicket. It had been under covers for quite some time, and that may have helped Punjab a bit. Credit to their bowlers for exploiting those conditions. But as a batting unit, we should’ve been good enough to post a competitive total.Our bowling unit has been consistent and doing really well. Even with the bat, there was good intent—it didn’t click today, but sometimes that’s how it goes. It’s just a matter of time before it all comes together.We face Punjab again in a few days. Our focus will be on correcting the errors in the batting department—we’ll review, reset, and come back stronger."

 

Shreyas Iyer | Punjab Kings Captain:
"Variety is the spice of life—and this season, we’ve certainly experienced all kinds of games!Tonight, a lot of our decisions were instinctive. Marco Jansen used the bounce beautifully, and the rest of the bowling unit backed him up brilliantly. Honestly, I didn’t expect the surface to play the way it did, but the bowlers adapted really well.One observation—I didn’t see a single six hit straight down the ground off a pacer, which shows how tricky the pitch was.Nehal was outstanding with his approach—composed, proactive, and very effective.I also had a personal chat with Chahal. He’s got the quality to bounce back anytime. In fact, I’d say he’s probably been the best bowler in the IPL so far. Of course, performance also depends on the surface, but he’s always in the game."
 

Tim David | Player of the Match:
"It didn’t feel all that easy out there tonight.I had a chance to assess the conditions and get a feel for how the pitch was playing, which helped me adapt as the innings went on.Look, our coaching staff has built this squad with clear roles in mind—we’ve got batters who bring different strengths. I’m just happy to contribute in whatever role is asked of me.Sure, it was nice to face a few more balls today, but I won’t be asking any questions about my position—I trust the team’s plans.The key tonight was building partnerships. It was a tricky surface, and we had to manage our risks carefully. I’m pleased with how I played, but I’ll feel even better enjoying a drink after a solid win.It’s been a bit of a challenge this season—we’ve encountered different conditions in almost every game. Tonight’s pitch had been under the covers, and we haven’t quite nailed it at home yet. That’s something we’ve got to acknowledge and improve upon."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Mumbai Indians vs Sunrisers Hyderabad
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Mumbai Indians Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, buckle up for tonight’s blockbuster at the Wankhede—Mumbai Indians versus Sunrisers Hyderabad. Both sides are neck and neck in the standings with just two wins apiece, and this clash isn’t just another fixture—it’s a battle for survival. Stakes are sky-high, and there’s no room for error.

Mumbai Indians, led by Hardik Pandya, are feeling the heat. The Wankhede hasn’t been the fortress it once was, and the pressure is piling up. All eyes will be on Jasprit Bumrah, who must deliver with the new ball, especially under the lights where the ball does a bit early on. Rohit Sharma at the top needs to anchor, and the middle order has to click—no excuses.

Sunrisers Hyderabad come in with their tails up after a record-breaking chase in their last outing. Abhishek Sharma’s 141 off 55 balls was a showstopper, and Travis Head continues to be a menace up top. Add Heinrich Klaasen’s brute power in the middle, and you’ve got a batting unit that can decimate any attack on its day.

Historically, MI leads SRH 13-10, but past records mean little tonight. Expect fireworks, strategic masterstrokes, and a contest that could redefine both teams' seasons. This is the IPL at its finest—edge-of-the-seat action awaits.



IPL Stats at Wankhede Stadium Since 2024:


 

Pitch Report | Murali Kartik & Michael Clarke

"I’m standing here at the South end of the stadium, and let’s take a look at the dimensions. It’s 60 meters to my right, 67 to the left, and straight down the ground is 73 meters.We’re on Pitch Number 6, which traditionally has seen low scores—but let’s not dwell on history. What matters is what’s on offer today. I’m told the surface was watered this morning, and with the sun beating down, it still feels a bit damp. There’s definitely some moisture underneath.It actually looks like a really good pitch. Yes, there’s a bit of moisture as Kartik mentioned, but there’s also a nice grass cover, which should provide consistency.One end does look drier, so we might see some turn for the spinners. But overall, I think it’s going to play beautifully.I’d expect both teams to prefer chasing, given the conditions. Doesn’t seem like there will be much dew tonight, so that shouldn’t be a factor.I certainly hope so, buddy! Looks like a good cricket wicket. Should offer something for everyone—early movement for the quicks, grip for the spinners, and once batters get in, it could be great to watch."It’s a red-soil surface, so yes, that should definitely help the spinners as the game progresses. Let’s see how it plays out!"
