Mumbai Indians complete a thrilling 4-wicket win with 11 balls to spare, chasing down 163 in a match that ebbed and flowed throughout! It was a team performance built on cameos — Rickelton, Rohit, Jacks, SKY, and Pandya all chipped in, before Tilak Varma coolly sealed it with a reverse sweep.

SRH’s 162/5 looked competitive on a slightly tacky surface. Abhishek Sharma gave them a blazing start with a 28-ball 40, while Klaasen played a mature hand with 37 off 28. MI’s bowlers pulled things back, with Jasprit Bumrah and Will Jacks keeping things tight.

In reply, MI’s top order played with intent — Rohit cracked 26 off 16, while Jacks (36) and SKY (26) ensured MI stayed ahead in the chase. Though Cummins picked three key wickets, MI had too much firepower in the end, despite a couple of late strikes from Eshan Malinga. 

 

Pat Cummins | SRH Captain:
"It wasn’t the easiest wicket to bat on today. We were probably a few runs short—would’ve liked to get a bit more on the board. You usually expect this surface to be fast and fluent, but it just didn’t play that way.Credit to the opposition—they bowled really well and managed to shut down a lot of our strong hitting zones. We felt we had most of our bases covered, but with 160, you always feel just a little under par.With the ball, we gave it a good crack. We knew we needed wickets early. We had plenty of death bowling options, and that’s why we brought Rahul in as the Impact Player—to give us that flexibility with 1-2 overs if needed.To make the final, you've got to play well away from home, and unfortunately, things haven’t quite clicked for us on the road this season. We’ve got a short break now, and then we regroup.We speak about assessing conditions every game, and I thought the boys did a good job getting through the powerplay without reckless hitting.Next one’s at home—we know that venue really well, and we’re looking forward to bouncing back there." 

 

Hardik Pandya | Mumbai Indians Captain:
"The way we bowled today was smart and spot on. We stuck to our basics, kept things simple, and quickly figured out which deliveries were tough to hit. That’s where we managed to squeeze them and control the game.
It looked like a decent track with a bit of grass. Deepak bowled a few deliveries that held up a little, so we sensed that change of pace could be effective. We tried to mix it up—not just slower ones, because if you bowl them too often, batters can line you up. We balanced it well with yorkers too, which disrupted their rhythm.
That’s the beauty of someone like Will. He brings all three facets to the table—brilliant in the field, delivers those handy overs, and with the bat, he’s explosive. That’s exactly why we back him—he’s a complete package.
At one point, when we needed 42 off 42, it felt like a tricky phase. We didn’t want to get carried away and lose a couple of wickets in excitement. So we consciously took a couple of overs to settle in. We knew the boundaries would come, and once we absorbed that pressure, we were able to press the accelerator at the right time.It’s going to be a packed house, no doubt. We’re expecting a great atmosphere and a high-quality game. For now, it's about resting well and coming back fresh to go again." 

 

Will Jacks | Player of the Match:
"Yeah, it’s been a slow start—not just for me personally, but for the team as well. Honestly, it’s been incredibly frustrating at times. Even tonight, I didn’t begin well—dropped a catch on the first ball. It came at me with pace, and I was just a bit late to react. Still, no excuses—I should’ve taken it. Glad I could pull things back later in the game.It’s taken me a little while to settle into the new franchise, but I’m feeling comfortable and confident now. It’s a great setup with plenty of star players around to learn from, and I’m just trying to absorb as much as I can. We’re starting to click as a team, and this was a brilliant win tonight. Hopefully, we can keep the momentum going.'Playable' is a good word for how I see myself. I’m always ready to do whatever’s required for the team—whether that means batting at 7 or bowling a few overs. As long as there’s clear communication about my role, I’m happy to adapt. At the end of the day, if the team’s winning, that’s all that matters to me.On this pitch, if you’re bowling slower balls, you have to bowl them into the wicket—it’s what the surface demanded.I’ve also been working hard on being more aggressive against spin, and I’ll continue to build on that aspect of my game."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Delhi Capitals vs Rajasthan Royals
Matchsummary.Commentss: Delhi Capitals Won by Super Over
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Rajasthan Royals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.Comments: Delhi Capitals Won by Super Over
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, get ready for a blockbuster showdown tonight as the Delhi Capitals take on the Rajasthan Royals at the Arun Jaitley Stadium in the heart of the capital. This is match number 32 of the IPL 2025 season, and it's shaping up to be a cracker.

The Capitals have been in scintillating form this season, with their top order firing on all cylinders. Their bowlers have been equally impressive, keeping the opposition in check with disciplined performances. A win tonight could see them climb to the top of the points table, a testament to their consistency and hunger for success.

On the other hand, the Royals have had a turbulent journey so far, managing only two wins from their six outings. Their batting lineup has struggled to find rhythm, and their bowlers have been unable to apply sustained pressure. However, the Royals are known for their resilience, and a victory tonight could be the spark they need to turn their season around.

The Arun Jaitley Stadium is known for its high-scoring encounters, and with both teams boasting explosive batsmen, we can expect a run-fest under the lights. The pitch will likely favour the batsmen, but the bowlers who can adapt quickly and execute their plans will be the ones to watch.

As the sun sets over Delhi, the stage is set for an enthralling contest between two teams with contrasting fortunes. Will the Capitals continue their march towards the playoffs, or will the Royals script a comeback for the ages? Only time will tell, but one thing is certain – we're in for a thrilling ride tonight!

 
 

Pitch Report – Graeme Swann & Shane Watson

"We’re here at the Arun Jaitley Stadium in Delhi—an gorgeous venue to play cricket. But let’s be honest, it’s not the biggest place for bowlers to enjoy! The boundaries are short—61 meters to my right, 62 to the left, and 72 straight down the ground. Not exactly a comforting sight for the bowlers—you can feel the pressure with these dimensions. The surface is a little dry again, similar to the previous match. There’s a good amount of grass cover on top, but it’s patchy in parts, which means it’ll offer something for the bowlers too. While batting first has worked well here—last season’s average winning first-innings score was around 230—this pitch still offers some grip for the spinners and some assistance for pacers who vary their pace. All in all, it’s a well-balanced pitch. Batters will fancy their chances, especially with the small boundaries, but bowlers who hit the right areas and mix things up will get rewards too. Given the setup, we’re in for a great contest!"

Super Over:
RR:- 11/2
DC:- 13/0
 

In what was the first Super Over of IPL 2025, the Delhi Capitals held their nerve to register a dramatic win over the Rajasthan Royals and became the first team to get 10 points this season. This match had everything—early fireworks, momentum shifts, heartbreaks, and a finish for the ages.

Rajasthan, chasing 189, started with a bang through Jaiswal and Samson, who raced to 61/0. But the tide turned when Sanju Samson walked off injured with a suspected side strain. Nitish Rana tried to take the innings deep with a crisp 51(28), but DC’s bowlers kept chipping away. The final over from Mitchell Starc was a masterclass, defending nine runs with two pinpoint yorkers and two run-outs.

Earlier, Axar Patel’s 34(14) and Stubbs' 34(18)* helped DC reach 188 after a middle-overs stutter. In reply, RR matched that exactly, taking it to the Super Over. But that’s when Stubbs smashed Sandeep Sharma for a match-winning six to seal the deal. 


 

Sanju Samson | Rajasthan Royals Captain:
"The injury feels alright now. I just wasn’t ready to come back out and bat at the time, but we’ll assess it tomorrow and see how it goes.I thought we bowled really well overall. There were moments when they came at us hard, but credit to our bowlers—we showed great energy in the field.That target was definitely within reach considering the batting lineup we have. But full credit to Starcy—he’s one of the best in the world. The way he bowled the 20th over, he won them the game.The plan was simple: swing hard. We knew he’d come at us, and we had to respond with intent.Sandeep Sharma has been my go-to in the toughest phases—powerplay, the 18th, the 20th. He’s delivered time and again. Archer bowled well too. But Starc simply took the game away in those final moments.A win tonight could’ve really lifted spirits in the dressing room, but we need to keep moving forward."
 

 

Axar Patel | Delhi Capitals Captain:
"We started well, but I felt we could’ve shown a bit more intent through the middle. The pitch wasn’t easy—the batters mentioned that—and I told them to keep the intent high regardless.The ball was sticking slightly. Set batters found it manageable, but it was tough for new batters to come in and score freely. That’s why I called for the Strategic Time-Out, just to reset and remind everyone that boundaries wouldn’t come easy. We adjusted our plans and you could see the difference.When a new batter comes in on such a pitch, the pressure builds—whether to rotate strike or go for the big hits.Personally, I had a minor finger injury from the Champions Trophy earlier this season. But as captain, I always want to contribute—today, it all came together with both bat and ball.I was confident that if Starc could execute, he’d bring us back into the game—and he did just that. He nailed his yorkers in the 20th over and the Super Over. That’s why he’s a legend of the game. His mentality is top-class."

 

Mitchell Starc | Player of the Match
"For me, it’s all about backing my execution. If you’ve got a clear plan and stick to it, more often than not, things work out. A little bit of luck always helps too. It was a fantastic game, and I’m glad we came out on the right side of it.I’ve been around long enough that most people know what’s coming from me. But execution is key. You play that over 10 different times, and you might get 10 different results. Fortunately, tonight, I executed well enough to take it to a Super Over.I was surprised they sent out left-handers—it suited the ball tailing into them. I got a couple of lucky breaks, especially with the wide line. But we’ve got the batting depth to chase it down, and in the end, it was a solid win.It’s a great mix of youth and experience. Axar’s leading the side well. We’ve got guys like Faf, KL, and Tristan who’ve played plenty of cricket and bring a lot of calm. There’s real talent in the squad and a lot of fun being had. Success always helps, and tonight’s win should build great momentum going forward."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Punjab Kings vs Kolkata Knight Riders
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Punjab Kings Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, strap yourselves in – because tonight in Mullanpur, it’s not just a match, it’s a blockbuster waiting to explode! The Punjab Kings, still nursing wounds from a heartbreaking loss despite scoring 245 in their last outing, return to their fortress looking for redemption. Shreyas Iyer – calm, collected, and carrying a touch of vengeance – leads this Punjab side with fire in the belly, especially as he lines up against his old brigade, the Kolkata Knight Riders.

On the other side, KKR walk in with their heads held high after a commanding win over CSK. Ajinkya Rahane’s men are clicking into gear, with their spin twins – Sunil Narine and Varun Chakaravarthy – strangling oppositions like seasoned maestros. Narine, with 34 scalps against Punjab in his career, is a man on a mission. 

For Punjab, Iyer’s strike rate of over 208 has been box-office, but the Kings need more from the likes of Glenn Maxwell, who’s yet to light the stage. The pitch at Mullanpur has been a belter. 200+ is par, and the bowlers know they’re entering a lion’s den tonight.

In 33 previous encounters, KKR lead 21-12, but history has little meaning when the stakes are this high. Both teams have the arsenal. Both are desperate for consistency. And when desperation meets talent under the lights – fireworks are guaranteed.
 

 

 Pitch Report |  Danny Morrison & Simon Katich

"Great to be back here! This ground always brings excitement, and there’s definitely a bias in terms of dimensions. To my right, it's a solid 70 meters—that's a decent hit. But to my left, it shortens up to just 61 meters, and it's 75 meters straight down the ground.Now, time for some insight into the 22 yards itself. It’s absolutely rock hard—really firm underfoot. That means the ball should come nicely onto the bat.This season, every time a team has batted first here, they’ve crossed 200 and successfully defended it. So, the toss becomes very interesting tonight.What’s also notable is that despite being at home, the Punjab Kings haven’t had much success here. They’ve played seven matches at this venue and have only managed two wins. It hasn’t been a happy hunting ground—yet.That said, this is a new-look Punjab Kings side, and they’ve got serious firepower with the bat. However, their powerplay bowling has been a concern—they haven’t taken many early wickets this season.KKR’s spinners will have a big role to play tonight, and with Lockie Ferguson ruled out due to injury, it’ll be interesting to see how both teams approach their tactics."



TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
 

???? Toss ????@PunjabKingsIPL won the toss and opted to bat first against @KKRiders.

Updates ?? https://t.co/sZtJIQpcbx#TATAIPL | #PBKSvKKR pic.twitter.com/ZkwM17fknM

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 15, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
PBKS:- 54/4 (9 rpo, 5x4, 4x6) || KKR:- 55/2 (9.16 rpo, 7x4, 2x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
PBKS:- 55/4 (6.11 rpo, 5x4, 2x6) || KKR:- 40/7 (4.44 rpo, 1x4, 2x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20)
PBKS:- 2/2 in 0.3 overs (4 rpo, 0x4, 0x6) || KKR:- 0/1 in 0.1 overs (0 rpo, 0x4, 0x6)
 

In what will go down as one of the most astonishing IPL heists of all time, Punjab Kings defended a modest 111 to script a 16-run win against the Kolkata Knight Riders in Mullanpur! A fiery 30(15) from Prabhsimran and 22(12) from Priyansh Arya gave them a spark initially. Yet, it was the bowlers who wrote the fairytale ending. Marco Jansen (3/17) was sensational with pace and bounce, while Yuzvendra Chahal turned the tide with a masterclass (4/28), claiming the likes of Rahane, Raghuvanshi, Rinku and Ramandeep.KKR were cruising at 62/2 but collapsed to 95 all out, losing 8 wickets for just 33 runs! Even the mighty Dre Russ couldn’t rescue them, bowled by Jansen to seal a famous win.With every KKR batter falling to pressure, PBKS’ bowling unit showed immense character to pull off the lowest 20-over total defended in IPL history 

 

Ajinkya Rahane | KKR Captain:
"Nothing much to explain—everyone saw what happened. I'm extremely disappointed with the performance. I’ll take the blame—I played a poor shot. Even though it looked like it was missing, I wasn’t sure enough to take the review. I had a quick chat with Angkrish, and he said it might be umpire’s call, but I didn’t want to take a chance at that point. That was our discussion, we weren't really thinking about NRR. We just batted poorly as a unit. There's no running away from that—we take full responsibility.Our bowlers did a great job, especially on this surface, to restrict a strong Punjab batting lineup to 111. From a batting point of view, on this wicket, playing with a straight bat was more effective. The sweep was hard to execute. Intent is important, yes, but we needed to play proper cricketing shots. We were reckless. Honestly, right now, a lot is going on in my head. It was an easy chase, and we let it slip. Once I go back to the dressing room, I need to calm down, collect my thoughts, and then speak to the boys. We still have half the tournament ahead of us. We need to stay positive, address our mistakes, and move forward with clarity."
 

Shreyas Iyer | PBKS Captain:
"It’s hard to put into words what just happened. The ball was turning, and I told Yuzi [Chahal] to really give it a rip—we wanted to stay aggressive, and thankfully, the right players stood up at the right time.These kinds of wins—tough, gritty ones—they give you momentum down the line.When I went out to bat, a couple of deliveries behaved strangely—one stayed low, one kicked up from the bottom. Even the batters who are good at sweeping were struggling, which told us there was variable bounce.That awareness helped. We asked our bowlers to keep the stumps in play and let the pitch do the work.Those two quick wickets early in the second innings shifted the momentum our way. And once Yuzi started spinning it big, belief started growing. We kept attacking fields, backed our bowlers, and forced them to take risks.It’s important to stay humble after a win like this. We’ll take the confidence from it, build on the momentum, and focus on improving in the games to come."
 

Yuzvendra Chahal | Player of the Match:
"It was a total team effort. We stayed positive and believed that if we could pick up 2–3 wickets in the powerplay, we’d put the opposition under real pressure.The pitch was on the slower side, and it was offering turn—which worked in our favourWhen I bowled my first delivery and saw it turn, Shreyas immediately asked if I wanted a slip. I didn’t hesitate—I asked for it straightaway. The mindset was clear: we were going for wickets to win the game.I went for 56 runs in the last match, but I had the confidence to bounce back. I believed I could change the game in the middle overs, and that self-belief made the difference today.My approach is always to aim for a wicket from the very first ball. Against Ajju bhai (Ajinkya Rahane), I mixed up my pace deliberately—to make it harder for him to go after me.Winning low-scoring games like this really lifts the team’s morale. These are the kind of gritty wins that bring everyone together.And on a personal note—it feels special. This is my first Player of the Match award for Punjab, and I’m really happy it came in such a memorable game."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Lucknow Super Giants vs Chennai Super Kings
Matchsummary.GroundName: Bharat Ratna Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee Ekana Cricket Stadium

Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.Comments: Chennai Super Kings Won by 5  Wickets
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The Bharat Ratna Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee Ekana Cricket Stadium sets the stage for a high-stakes showdown as Lucknow Super Giants host Chennai Super Kings in a battle of contrasting campaigns. LSG, brimming with confidence, sit comfortably in the top four with four wins from six games. Their success has been built on team depth and individual brilliance—Nicholas Pooran's five fifties in six matches underline their batting firepower, while Shardul Thakur has stepped up with the ball, becoming the tournament’s second-highest wicket-taker.

In stark contrast, CSK are grappling with one of their most forgettable seasons. Just one win in six matches and a faltering batting unit—highlighted by Rachin Ravindra's modest 149-run tally—have left them languishing at the bottom. The return of MS Dhoni to captaincy hasn't reversed their fortunes, and despite Noor Ahmad’s Purple Cap-worthy performance (12 wickets), their famed spin attack has largely underwhelmed.

LSG have won three of their last five encounters against CSK and will look to extend that dominance on home turf. With both pride and playoff hopes on the line for CSK, and LSG eyeing consolidation, expect fireworks in this must-watch clash between the Super Giants and the Super Kings.


 

Pitch Report | Daren Ganga & Michael Clarke:
"The Ekana Stadium lights up tonight to host Match 30—a crucial contest for both sides. CSK will be desperate to snap their five-match losing streak.We’re on Pitch Number 5 today, positioned right in the center of the square. The boundary dimensions are fairly balanced—66 meters on either side and 73 meters straight down the ground. Behind the stumps, it's slightly shorter at 59 meters, something the batters will definitely keep in mind.The curator tells us this is a hybrid pitch—about 70% black soil and 30% red. Historically, teams haven’t crossed the 200-run mark too often here.The wicket looks promising, but I suspect it might play a little two-paced—that’s probably due to the blend of black and red soil. You can see some inconsistencies in the surface, and that could make strokeplay a bit tricky.It reminds me a bit of the Hyderabad wicket—there are some grass patches here as well. As the game progresses, pace variations from the fast bowlers will be key. Slower balls and cutters could be very effective today.With conditions like these, both teams will be aiming to adapt quickly and grab those all-important two points."

 

TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Field

 

???? Toss ????@ChennaiIPL elected to field against @LucknowIPL

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 14, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1 - 6 Overs) :
LSG: 42/2 (7 rpo, 5x4, 2x6) || CSK: 59/1 (9.83 rpo, 11x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (7 - 15 Overs) :
LSG: 67/2 (7.4 rpo, 5x4, 4x6) || CSK: 51/4 (5.67 rpo, 2x4, 1x6)

Death Overs (16 - 20 Overs) :
LSG: 57/3 (11.4 rpo, 1x4, 4x6) || CSK: 58/0 (12.89 rpo, 7x4, 2x6)

 

Chennai Super Kings returned to winning ways with a composed five-wicket victory over Lucknow Super Giants at the Ekana Stadium, snapping a five-match losing streak and reigniting their IPL 2025 campaign. Chasing 167, CSK’s revamped opening pair of Shaik Rasheed and Rachin Ravindra provided a much-needed solid start, adding 52 runs in the Powerplay. While Rasheed impressed on debut with a fluent 27, Ravindra top-scored with 37, showing early aggression.A middle-overs slowdown, triggered by the spin trio of Ravi Bishnoi, Aiden Markram, and Digvesh Singh, put CSK under pressure, reducing them to 111/5. However, Shivam Dube (43* off 37) and MS Dhoni (26* off 11) steadied the ship and expertly finished the chase.Earlier, Rishabh Pant anchored the LSG innings with a well-crafted 63 off 49. Cameos from Mitchell Marsh, Ayush Badoni, and Abdul Samad pushed LSG to 166/7. CSK’s bowling unit, led by Ravindra Jadeja (2/24) and Matheesha Pathirana (2/45), maintained control despite occasional bursts of momentum from LSG.With this result, CSK not only claim two points but also rebuild momentum heading into the second half of the season.


 

Rishabh Pant | LSG Captain:
"We feel we were about 10–15 runs short today. We kept losing wickets at key moments—every time we had some momentum, we lost a wicket and couldn’t build a strong partnership.The wicket was decent to bat on, though slightly tricky at times. I still feel we could’ve added 10 more runs to the total.
I’m feeling better with each game. Sometimes, even when you're hitting the ball well, it just doesn’t come off. For me, it’s about finding rhythm and taking things one game at a time.We had time to think about the options. The plan was to take it deep, but it just didn’t go our way in the end.Our powerplay bowling has been a bit of a concern—something we’re looking to sort out as the tournament progresses. But credit to the bowlers, they pulled things back really well in the middle overs.As a team, we’re focused on staying positive and continuing to improve with each game." 
 

MS Dhoni | CSK Captain & Player of the Match:
"It’s always good to win—especially in a tournament like this. Things haven’t quite gone our way lately, but a win like this gives us a lot of confidence. It was a tough game, but I’m glad we ended up on the winning side.In the powerplay, we struggled a bit to find rhythm with the ball. But the middle overs were solid, and we finished strongly at the death. That’s something we’ve been able to do well—bounce back even when the opposition gets a good start, and pull things back to keep them to a par score.We haven’t been getting the kind of starts we’re looking for as a batting unit, and the frequent fall of wickets has been concerning. One factor could be the nature of the Chennai pitches—they’ve been a bit on the slower side. Interestingly, our batting performances have been better away from home. As a group, it’s important that we keep expressing ourselves.At the moment, our bowling unit is doing better than our batting. We’ve made a few changes to the attack—we needed bowlers who could deliver in the powerplay. Earlier, we were putting too much pressure on Ash, having him bowl two overs up front. This new setup gives us more balance, and I believe this attack is more effective overall.That said, the batting still needs improvement. We're losing wickets at crucial times, so we need someone to play the anchoring role. We’ve trained for that, and it’s important for everyone to execute their roles consistently.I thought he batted really well today. He’s been with us for a while—last year he showed promise, and this season he’s looked very good in the nets. What sets him apart is that he plays authentic cricket shots—he doesn’t just slog. He has the potential to dominate in a classy way.Honestly, even I was surprised when I got the award! I thought Noor bowled brilliantly today. Our new-ball bowlers also did a fantastic job. But I’ll take it with a smile."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Delhi Capitals vs Mumbai Indians
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Delhi Capitals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The Arun Jaitley Stadium in Delhi is set to host a high-stakes IPL 2025 clash tonight as the Delhi Capitals (DC) take on the Mumbai Indians (MI). DC, under Axar Patel's leadership, have been dominant this season, securing four consecutive victories and leading the points table. KL Rahul has been instrumental, amassing 185 runs, including a notable 93* against RCB. Their bowling attack, featuring Mitchell Starc and Kuldeep Yadav, has been equally impressive, with Starc claiming 9 wickets and Kuldeep 

In contrast, MI have struggled, managing only one win in five matches. Their top order, including Rohit Sharma and Will Jacks, has underperformed, and their bowling unit has lacked consistency. However, the return of Jasprit Bumrah offers a glimmer of hope. 

Historically, MI lead the head-to-head with 19 wins to DC's 16, but DC have a better record at home, winning 7 out of 12 matches at the Arun Jaitley Stadium.The pitch is expected to be batting-friendly, suggesting a high-scoring encounter.

As the Capitals aim to maintain their unbeaten streak and MI look to revive their campaign, tonight's match promises to be a thrilling contest.


 

IPL Stats At Arun Jaitley Stadium Since 2024:

 

Pitch Report | Danny Morrison & Murali Kartik

"It’s the first game of the season in the Capital—Delhi up against Mumbai. Now, this ground has some interesting dimensions. To my right, it’s just 60 meters—a real treat for the batters. To my left, it stretches out to 66 meters, and straight down the ground, it’s 72 meters.This is a six-hitting ground—they do it for fun here. The highest score at this venue is 235, and it’s not uncommon to see sixes flying all around.Looking at the surface today, it’s got that straw-colored grass on top and quite a few visible cracks. It’s not as flat as it may look at first glance.That said, I don’t think it’ll have much impact on the run-scoring. Over the past year, more teams have won here after batting first. So, if you win the toss—go ahead, set a target, and back yourself to defend it."

???? Toss ????@DelhiCapitals won the toss and elected to bowl against @mipaltan in Delhi.

Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
MI: 59/1 (9.83 rpo, 7x4, 3x6) || DC: 72/1 (12 rpo 10x4, 2x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
MI: 87/3 (9.66 rpo, 8x4, 5x6) || DC: 86/4 (9.55 rpo 8x4, 4x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20)
MI: 59/1 (11.8 rpo, 6x4, 2x6) || DC: 35/5 (8.75 rpo 3x4, 1x6) 
 

In a game that had everything — quick starts, aggressive batting, mid-innings collapses, and three run-outs in three balls to finish the match — Mumbai Indians edged Delhi Capitals by 12 runs to register a pulsating win at the Arun Jaitley Stadium.

Batting first, Mumbai Indians posted a competitive 205/5, riding on impactful contributions from Tilak Varma (59 off 33) and Ryan Rickelton (41 off 25). Suryakumar Yadav chipped in with 40 (28) while Naman Dhir's unbeaten 38 off 17 gave MI the final flourish. Kuldeep Yadav was the standout bowler for DC, returning excellent figures of 2/23 in 4 overs.

In reply, Karun Nair played one of the innings of the tournament, smashing 89 off just 40 balls, but lacked support from the other end. After his dismissal, the Capitals crumbled under pressure, losing 8 wickets for 74 runs. Karn Sharma (3/36) and Mitchell Santner (2/43) triggered the collapse.

But it was the penultimate over that defined the drama — three run-outs in three balls, courtesy of MI's sharp fielding and DC's poor running between the wickets, sealed the deal for the visitors.

With this win, Mumbai Indians climb up the table, while Delhi Capitals are left pondering missed opportunities and what could’ve been. 


 

Axar Patel | DC Captain:
We actually had the game in our hands. But I think a few soft dismissals from the middle order and some poor shot selections cost us. Losing by just 12 runs with an over to spare—it was still within reach.You can’t always rely on the lower order to pull off chases. There’ll be days when shots don’t come off, and that's fine—no point overthinking it.I thought 205 was a very chaseable target. The pitch was good and there was dew settling in too. Maybe if we’d fielded a bit better and held onto our catches, we could’ve restricted them to a few less.On the bowling front, I have a lot of confidence in our spin trio. Two of them can bowl in the powerplay, and Kuldeep—he’s been unbelievable this season. Whenever we need a breakthrough, I know I can count on him.There were a lot of positives to take from this game. We just need to move on and not dwell on it." 

 

Hardik Pandya | MI Captain:
"Absolutely—winning always feels special, especially in games like this where you’re unsure until the 13th over about which way it’ll swing.We were running out of options with the way he was batting. He took his chances and showed the kind of hard work he's put in over the years. To come in and go like that—credit to him.Outstanding from Karn. Bowling in a stadium with short boundaries isn’t easy, but he showed great heart. He kept tossing it up, stayed brave, and really showed his character tonight.I’ve always believed fielding can completely flip a game. Tonight, we were sharp—backing each other up, staying switched on. And that made a huge difference.It’s always situation-dependent. We want to give more time in the middle to players who are in form. With the heavy dew, it was a bit tricky. We’ll continue to assess and adapt the order based on conditions.One thing we keep reminding ourselves: the game isn’t over until it’s actually over. As long as we show character and fight for every moment, momentum can swing our way. Tonight was proof of that."

 

Karn Sharma | Player of the Match:
"It’s a great feeling. I’ve always trusted my process, and it feels really good when the hard work starts paying off.Whenever I get a chance, I just want to make the most of it. Whether I’m in the playing XI or not, I keep working hard. At the end of the day, only 11 or 12 players can make it into the game—it’s all about team combination.I think KL Rahul’s wicket was the turning point for us. That catch came at a crucial moment. I always pray a lot—for wins, for moments like these.We also changed the ball, which helped us. With the dew coming in, the fresh ball was a bit drier, making it easier to grip. That made a difference in the end."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Rajasthan Royals vs Royal Challengers Bengaluru

Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.Comments: Royal Challengers Bengaluru Won by 9  Wickets
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The Sawai Mansingh Stadium in Jaipur is ready to welcome its first match of the TATA IPL 2025 season as Rajasthan Royals (RR) take on Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) in Match 28. With both sides coming off losses in their previous fixtures, this encounter carries extra weight as teams jostle for mid-table positioning.

RR have managed two wins from five matches, and while their batting has shown promise, it’s been a bit topsy-turvy — moments of brilliance have been followed by untimely collapses. The return to rhythm for Jofra Archer has been a big positive, with the speedster bowling with great control and pace. Maheesh Theekshana has been among the wickets and has kept the run flow in check during the middle overs. Playing their first match at home this season, RR will hope for a strong all-round show to capitalise on familiar conditions.

RCB, on the other hand, have three wins from five games — all secured on the road. Their batting has largely been powered by Phil Salt, Rajat Patidar, and Virat Kohli, who’ve handled the bulk of the scoring. However, they’ll be eager for more support from the rest of the line-up to deliver a well-rounded performance. The availability of Wanindu Hasaranga remains uncertain due to personal reasons, which could leave a gap in their spin attack.

With both teams aiming to bounce back and Jaipur finally getting into the IPL action, fans can expect an intense battle in the pink city. 

 

IPL Stats At Sawai Mansingh Stadium Since 2024:


 

Pitch Report – Deep Dasgupta & Varun Aaron

"We’re here for the first game of the season in Jaipur—and it’s a hot afternoon, really intense out here, though there's a bit of breeze. Now, let’s talk dimensions. It’s one of the larger venues in the country—62 meters on one side, 69 meters on the other, and straight down the ground it’s 74 meters. This looks like a really good wicket. Last year, we saw two games played here—one of them also an afternoon clash—and both went 190-plus. This ground has a solid batting history. Virat Kohli got a century here last season. Sanju Samson has racked up 150 runs at this venue without getting dismissed. Riyan Parag averages 60 here—it’s been a happy hunting ground for batters. Now, if we take a closer look, there are a few cracks on the surface but also some grass—not live grass, more like dead grass to bind the pitch. Overall, it looks like a flat batting deck. It might offer a bit to the spinners later in the second innings, but for the most part, it’s set up for runs. Expecting a high-scoring game; there could be some turn on offer later. So, would you prefer to bat first or chase here? Historically, teams batting first have had better results on this pitch. But to be honest, this wicket is good enough either way. It’ll all come down to which team plays better cricket today."

Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
RR:- 45/0 (7.5 rpo, 6x4, 1x6) || RCB:- 65/0 (10.83 rpo, 6x4, 4x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
RR:- 69/2 (7.66 rpo, 7x4, 1x6) || RCB:- 81/1 (9 rpo, 5x4, 4x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20) 
RR:- 59/2 (11.8 rpo, 5x4, 3x6) || RCB:- 29/1 in 2.3 Overs (11.6 rpo, 3x4, 1x6) 


 

Royal Challengers Bengaluru put on a clinical show to dismantle Rajasthan Royals by 9 wickets in Jaipur, recording their fourth consecutive away win of the season. Chasing 174 for victory, RCB's top-order blazed through the target in just 17.3 overs, with Phil Salt and Virat Kohli leading the charge.

Salt set the tone early, racing to 65 off just 33 balls with 5 fours and 6 sixes, dominating the Powerplay with ruthless intent. Though he fell to Kumar Kartikeya at 92, the momentum never dipped. Kohli, composed and calculated, anchored the chase with an unbeaten 62 off 45, while Devdutt Padikkal (40* off 28) applied the finishing touches with a flurry of boundaries. Earlier, Yashasvi Jaiswal’s fluent 75 powered Rajasthan to 173/4. Despite a strong start, the Royals lost their way in the middle overs. Krunal Pandya was economical (1/29), and Josh Hazlewood (1/26) removed the set Jaiswal at a crucial moment.

RCB’s commanding performance underlines their title credentials, now sitting third on the table. Rajasthan, meanwhile, will rue missed chances and a lacklustre bowling effort as they search for momentum heading into the business end of the tournament.


 

Sanju Samson | RR Captain:
 "Given the slow nature of the wicket, I felt 170-odd was actually a really good total after losing the toss. It wasn’t easy batting in the powerplay—we struggled, and we knew Salt and Kohli would come hard. Honestly, they won the game right there in the first six overs.Both sides missed chances—we dropped theirs, they dropped ours. But in the end, they simply batted better. Credit where it’s due—RCB showed more intent, and I have to admit, the toss did play a part.Ideally, I would’ve liked to take the game deeper, into the 19th or 20th over.The good thing is the dressing room is honest. Everyone acknowledges where we went wrong. The mindset is still positive—we’ve had a great season, and we need to leave this behind, bounce back fresh, and stay confident heading into the next one.It's all about moving on quickly and staying focused." 
 

Rajat Patidar | RCB Captain:
"It was an incredible performance. The bowlers really nailed their plans—it was great to watch.We didn’t have a fixed number in mind, but given how the pitch was behaving, especially in the powerplay, we thought 150–170 would be competitive.I draw a lot of confidence from them. They’re ready to bowl in any conditions, at any stage of the game.I really enjoyed Salt’s knock—it was something special. And the way VK bhai rotated the strike—it made a big difference.We don’t focus too much on the venue. Our mindset is to play positive cricket, wherever we go." 

Phil Salt | Player of the Match:
"Yeah, I’m really pleased with my performance—especially doing it away from home. This venue was a bit unfamiliar to me, and before the game, I’d said I wanted to give the team a solid start. Happy to have done exactly that today.I had a few plans in mind, but he was swinging the ball quite a bit. So I picked a particular area on the ground to target. Me and Jofra go way back—we’ve had a lot of battles in the nets. Honestly, he’s knocked me over more than anyone else. I’ve probably faced him the most. Feels nice to have one over him today. But we’ll be up against each other again in a few days.The wicket was a touch slower and lower. The powerplay gave me a chance to really make an impact. To be fair, Rajasthan batted well too. But our bowlers stuck to the plans and made them hit straight—exactly where we wanted. Overall, just a great team performance."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Sunrisers Hyderabad vs Punjab Kings
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Punjab Kings Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, buckle up! Tonight at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium, Hyderabad, it's a high-voltage clash between Sunrisers Hyderabad and Punjab Kings.Sunrisers Hyderabad, led by Pat Cummins, are in a bit of a pickle, having lost four on the trot. Their explosive start to the season has fizzled out, with the top order misfiring and the bowlers leaking runs. The likes of Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma need to rediscover their mojo, and fast.On the flip side, Punjab Kings are flying high. Shreyas Iyer's men have won three out of four, with young guns like Priyansh Arya stepping up big time. Their bowling attack, featuring Arshdeep Singh and Yuzvendra Chahal, has been spot on.The pitch at Hyderabad is a belter, offering something for everyone. Expect a run-fest, with both teams looking to outgun each other.
So, who will rise and who will fall? Will SRH break their losing streak, or will PBKS continue their winning ways? It's all to play for, and it's going to be a cracker of a contest!

 
 

Pitch Report | Pommie Mbangwa & Michael Clarke
 Square boundaries: 63m and 69m. Down the ground? A solid 77 meters.This is an absolute dream for the batters. Flat, hard, true surface. The only patch of green is behind the stumps. Expect the ball to come on nicely, and with the short square side, I’d say 230 to 240 is your par score tonight.That's big talk, but fair. This is pitch number two and historically, the average score here is 211 – but as we've seen, that's rarely enough to defend.Spot on. And here's the kicker – no dew expected tonight. So both captains have a fair shot, regardless of the toss. If you win it though – you bat first and bat big." 


TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
 

???? News from Hyderabad ????@PunjabKingsIPL elected to bat against @SunRisers in Match 2?7?

Updates ?? https://t.co/RTe7RlXDRq #TATAIPL | #SRHvPBKS pic.twitter.com/4wdG7f9eaE

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 12, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (Overs 1-6)
PBKS:- 89/1 (14.83 rpo, 9x4, 6x6) || SRH:- 83/0 (13.83 rpo, 12x4, 3x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7-15)
PBKS:- 88/3 (9.77 rpo, 4x4, 5x6) || SRH:- 122/1 (13.55 rpo, 9x4, 9x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16-20)
PBKS:- 68/2 (13.6 rpo, 5x4, 5x6)  || SRH:- 42/1 (12 rpo, 5x4, 2x6) 
 

Sunrisers Hyderabad stunned Punjab Kings with a record-smashing 8-wicket win at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium, chasing down a mammoth 246-run target in just 18.3 overs, the second-highest successful chase in IPL history.

Put in to bat, PBKS rode on a captain’s knock from Shreyas Iyer (82 off 36) and blazing cameos from Priyansh Arya (36 off 13) and Marcus Stoinis (34 off 11)* to post a daunting 245/6. Despite Harshal Patel’s four-wicket haul, SRH’s top order responded with brute force.

Abhishek Sharma delivered an innings of a lifetime, hammering a blistering 141 off just 55 balls, laced with 14 fours and 10 sixes, making it the highest individual score of IPL 2024. Travis Head’s 66 off 37 provided the perfect platform, and the duo’s 171-run opening stand left PBKS shell-shocked.

SRH sealed the chase with 9 balls to spare, Heinrich Klaasen applying the finishing touches. It was a night that will be remembered for Abhishek’s carnage, and for rewriting the record books under the lights of Uppal. 

 

Shreyas Iyer | PBKS Captain:
"It was a fantastic total, but honestly, I can’t help but laugh at how they chased it down with two overs to spare.We could’ve taken those two catches—those were key moments. He was lucky, yes, but it was an out-of-this-world knock. To sum it up, our bowling didn't meet expectations. We’ll need to go back to the drawing board and figure out how to bring out our best.I did give him credit—the way he struck the ball was incredible. The opening partnership left us with hardly any opportunities. I’ll admit, the over rotation on my part could’ve been better.That was a big blow. He’s someone who delivers 140+ consistently and picks up crucial wickets. But injuries are part of the game. No excuses though—we have other bowlers capable of winning matches.To be honest, we felt 230 would’ve been a good score. The pitch was gripping initially, but once the dew set in, batting got easier. Still, the way they batted—it’s one of the best knocks I’ve ever seen."
 

Pat Cummins | SRH Captain:
"Please, not these pitches in Australia for Test matches!As a bowling unit, we knew what we were walking into—it suits our style. But credit to the batters, they really showed what they’re capable of.Honestly, not many options here. Slower balls don’t stick—the ball just flies off the surface. Anything under 10 an over is a win.Chasing 250... they've done this before. It’s crazy, but they made it look possible.I’m a big fan of Abhi. We didn’t want to overthink, just stick to what makes us good players. That’s the strength of this squad—keeping it simple.The crowd was phenomenal—flags waving, packed stands. The support’s been awesome."
 

Abhishek Sharma | Player of the Match:
"It hasn’t been easy going through a rough patch. But a special thanks to the team and captain—they kept things simple for us batters, even when I wasn’t doing well.I had a good chat with Travis before the game—it was a special day for both of us. I usually don’t play too much behind the wicket, but on this pitch, I tried inventing some shots due to the bounce and dimensions.The whole team’s waiting for my parents—they’ve been lucky charms for the Orange Army.We didn’t over-complicate things; we just wanted to express ourselves and play naturally.This knock is very close to my heart. I badly wanted to break that losing streak. It was tough as a young player, but the team environment was so positive.Special thanks to Yuvi paaji—I’ve been speaking to him regularly. And to Suryakumar Yadav as well—he’s been a big support throughout."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Lucknow Super Giants vs Gujarat Titans
Matchsummary.GroundName: Bharat Ratna Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee Ekana Cricket Stadium
Matchsummary.Commentss: Lucknow Super Giants Won by 6  Wickets
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Lucknow Super Giants Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.Comments: Lucknow Super Giants Won by 6  Wickets
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The Bharat Ratna Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee Ekana Cricket Stadium in Lucknow will host a high-stakes afternoon clash as Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) take on Gujarat Titans (GT) in Match 26 of the TATA IPL 2025. With both teams in solid form, this daytime encounter promises to be a compelling watch.

Gujarat Titans, currently sitting at the top of the points table, are riding a wave of momentum. After a narrow defeat to Punjab Kings in their opener, they’ve bounced back emphatically with four consecutive wins. Their batting unit is firing on all cylinders — Jos Buttler has been providing brisk starts, while Sai Sudharsan has anchored the middle order with remarkable consistency. The real X-factor for GT, though, has been R Sai Kishore. The left-arm spinner has been exceptional, tying up batters with tight lines and picking up crucial wickets, particularly through the middle overs.

Lucknow Super Giants, placed sixth, have three wins from five matches. Nicholas Pooran has been in stellar form with the bat, finishing games with authority. Support from Mitchell Marsh and Aiden Markram has strengthened the middle order, giving LSG a well-rounded batting unit. With the match being played in familiar home conditions, LSG will look to bring their A-game and challenge Gujarat’s winning streak.

The pitch at Ekana is expected to assist slower bowlers, making this a tactical battle between two smartly built sides. A lot will depend on how both teams adapt during the afternoon heat and handle the slow, gripping surface.

  

 

Pitch Report |  Shane Watson & Murali Kartik
“We’re on Pitch No. 6 today, which has already seen runs galore. The black soil base and those big square boundaries—63m one side, 70m the other—should favor batters. Strangely enough, bowlers haven’t really enjoyed the help they might expect from such dimensions. It’s a good-looking strip with a healthy grass cover and a bit of shine. In the previous outing, LSG put up 203 here. The surface has enough bounce to allow pacers to dig it in short and extract something with change-ups. Five of the ten wickets last time came off balls that hit the deck.“This could be another high-scoring afternoon. With teams now finding success defending totals, the smart call might just be to win the toss and bat first.”



Venue Stats Since TATA IPL 2024 
 

TOSS UPDATE: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
 

???? Toss ????@LucknowIPL elected to field against @gujarat_titans

Updates ?? https://t.co/VILHBLEerV #TATAIPL | #LSGvGT pic.twitter.com/F8T97VJ5Mv

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 12, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs)
GT: 54/0 (9 rpo, 6x4, 1x6) || LSG: 61/0 (10.16 rpo, 9x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs)
GT: 81/3 (9 rpo, 8x4, 1x6)  || LSG: 93/2 (10.33 rpo, 5x4, 7x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs)
GT: 45/3 (9 rpo, 4x4, 1x6)  || LSG: 32/2 (7.11 rpo, 2x4, 1x6) 
 

At the Ekana Stadium, Lucknow Super Giants put on a complete show to outclass Gujarat Titans by six wickets and extend their winning streak to three. Chasing 181, the hosts were cool and calculated, with Aiden Markram’s classy 58 and Nicholas Pooran’s brutal 61 off 34 powering them past the finish line. Despite GT's late breakthroughs, Ayush Badoni and Abdul Samad held their nerve, finishing the game with poise under pressure.

Earlier, Gujarat looked set for a 200-plus total as Gill and Sudharsan stitched a 120-run opening stand, both notching fifties. But Avesh Khan’s breakthrough of Gill shifted the tide. LSG’s bowlers, led by Ravi Bishnoi (2/36) and Shardul Thakur (2/34), applied the brakes, with GT scoring just 60 in the last eight overs to end on 180/6. 

In reply, Aiden Markram's elegant 58 set the foundation, but it was Nicholas Pooran’s sensational 61 off 34 balls—an innings laced with seven towering sixes—that sealed the game for the hosts. Ayush Badoni’s calm cameo (28 off 20)* provided the finishing touches as LSG cruised home with three balls to spare. 


 

Shubman Gill | Gujarat Titans Captain 
"The wicket wasn't easy to score on from the start. Our plan was to take it to 18 overs, have someone bat through 50–60 balls once set, and aim for a total around 200–220.Losing back-to-back wickets really set us back. It was tough for any batter to get going initially, with the ball stopping a bit. Our strike rotation in the middle overs wasn’t up to the mark, and that’s something we need to improve.We were always aiming for wickets — that was the mindset. Yes, we were behind, but we believed that if we could pick 2–3 quick wickets, we could still push the game deep. And we did just that. We got breakthroughs after the 10th over, but the ball didn’t hold up as much as we expected in the end, especially with some dew coming in during the final phase.Still, fighting till the end was a good sign. That’s what we discussed during the second timeout — to stretch it as deep as we could. Thank you, everyone."
 

Rishabh Pant | Lucknow Super Giants Captain
"Definitely feeling happy. We’re sticking to the process, backing each other’s abilities, and focusing on one match at a time.The plan was to bowl yorkers and attack the stumps — the bowlers executed that brilliantly, which was great to see as captain.To be honest, I wasn’t too pleased with how things started, but it’s a T20 game — pressure moments are part of it. The way the boys pulled it back was fantastic.With each game, I’m feeling more confident. Marsh gave me a chance today, and I felt that spending more time at the crease would help me. It's about finding that rhythm. At the end of the day, it’s a team game — we all want to contribute and help the team win.One thing’s for sure — we’re lucky to have Nicholas Pooran on our side. He’s been outstanding with the bat. It’s definitely better to have him in your team than to bowl to him!"
 

Aiden Markram | Player of the Match 
"Yeah, definitely a slow surface. You want to start the tournament strong. My role has slightly changed, so it's been about adapting. The first few games didn’t go my way, but I’m grateful that things have improved in the last couple of knocks.It’s probably a mix of things — tight schedules and ever-changing conditions. Some players can clear the ropes at will; that might not be my main strength, so I just try to stick to what works for me.Early in the tournament, I felt I had to change my game to match others in terms of hitting boundaries. But I realized it's better to play to your strengths if it helps the team.Conditions did shift. Under the hot sun, it was slow and tricky, but under lights, it played better. If we play another day game, we’ll keep that in mind. Building partnerships will be key, especially since batting gets easier later on."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Chennai Super Kings vs Kolkata Knight Riders

Matchsummary.Comments: Kolkata Knight Riders Won by 8  Wickets
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
The stage is set at the MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai for a blockbuster clash as Chennai Super Kings  take on Kolkata Knight Riders  in Match 25 of the TATA IPL 2025. Both sides come into this game eager to turn their fortunes around, having suffered defeats in their previous outings.

Chennai Super Kings, five-time IPL champions, have endured a rough patch after a bright start. They opened their campaign with a memorable win over Mumbai Indians but have since lost four games on the bounce. To add to their woes, captain Ruturaj Gaikwad has been ruled out of the tournament with an elbow injury. In a much-anticipated twist, MS Dhoni   returns as captain, hoping to bring stability and inspiration to a side in need of direction. With the bat, CSK have lacked firepower and consistency, and they’ll need their experienced names to deliver. On the bowling front, Noor Ahmad has been a reliable spin option, while Khaleel Ahmed has impressed with his new-ball spells in the Powerplay.

Kolkata Knight Riders are also coming off a close loss, falling short by just four runs against Lucknow Super Giants in a high-scoring contest. With three defeats in five matches, KKR find themselves in the lower half of the table. While their batting has shown flashes of brilliance, they’ve struggled to close out games. This trip to Chepauk presents an opportunity to reset and bounce back with a statement performance.

With two heavyweights desperate for momentum, MS Dhoni’s captaincy return and Chepauk’s spin-friendly conditions add extra intrigue. Will CSK break their losing streak at home, or can KKR spoil the party and climb back up the table? Expect a fiery contest in Chennai.


Head to Head : 



IPL Stats at MA Chidambaram Stadium Since 2024 :



Pitch Report:

It’s a typical Chennai evening — warm, humid, but there’s a bit of breeze wafting through the iconic MA Chidambaram Stadium. And once again, spin, strategy, and smarts will come into play. Deep Dasgupta and Matthew Hayden gave us the lowdown from the centre, and it’s fascinating.

Tonight’s battle will unfold on a black soil deck that’s seen action once before — CSK’s only win this season vs MI. But unlike that slower surface, this one’s firmer, harder, and carries a lovely sheen of rolled-in grass, giving it a bit more bounce and pace.

The dimensions? Compact sideways — 68 and 65 meters — with a meatier 80 meters straight. That means batters will fancy going square, but the long straight boundaries will keep bowlers in the game.

Now here’s the kicker: if dew stays away, expect grip and bounce to play a part, especially for spinners. But batting second could become a breeze if it shows up like it did last night.

Haydos’ verdict? “Not quite a 200 surface, but much better for batting.” Expect competitive totals in the 170-180 range — and toss could be crucial tonight.




Toss Update:   has won the toss and elected to bowl first  

 

???? Toss ????@KKRiders won the toss and elected to bowl against @ChennaiIPL in Chennai.

Updates ? https://t.co/gPLIYGimQn#TATAIPL | #CSKvKKR pic.twitter.com/r2GTOQ6cvc

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 11, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1 - 6 Overs) :
CSK - 31/2 (5.16 rpo, 4x4, 0x6)  ll  KKR - 71/1 (11.83 rpo, 3x4, 7x6)

Middle Overs (7 - 15 Overs) :
CSK - 43/5 (4.77 rpo, 1x4, 1x6)  ll  KKR - 36/1 in 4.1 overs (8.64 rpo, 1x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (16 - 20 Overs) :
CSK - 29/2 (5.80 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)
 

Kolkata Knight Riders produced a clinical performance to register a dominant 8-wicket win over Chennai Super Kings in Match 25 of IPL 2025 at the MA Chidambaram Stadium. After winning the toss and opting to bowl first, KKR’s spinners completely dismantled CSK’s batting unit on a sluggish surface.

CSK were restricted to just 103/9 in their 20 overs — a total that never truly challenged the visitors. Shivam Dube top-scored with 31 off 29, while Vijay Shankar chipped in with 29 runs. The rest of the batting faltered badly against disciplined spells from Sunil Narine (3/13), Varun Chakaravarthy (2/22), and Harshit Rana (2/16). The hosts collapsed in clusters, losing wickets at regular intervals and failing to find any rhythm throughout the innings.

In reply, KKR made short work of the modest target, chasing it down in just 10.1 overs. Sunil Narine smashed a blistering 44 off 18 balls, setting the tone with his fearless hitting. Quinton de Kock (23) and Ajinkya Rahane (20*) provided support, while Rinku Singh (15* off 12) finished it off in style.


 

MS Dhoni (Chennai Super Kings Captain):
"Some nights just don’t roll in your favour, and this was another one of those. We’ve got to return to the basics, reassess where we’re faltering, and accept the challenge head-on. The truth is—we just didn’t have enough on the board today.

The ball was holding up again, like it has in a few games where we bowled first. But if you keep losing wickets in clusters, it doesn’t matter what the pitch is doing—it becomes a tough game. We never really stitched together a partnership and that put a lot of pressure on the incoming batters.

That said, it’s not all doom and gloom. We’ve played some solid cricket earlier this season. What’s crucial is that we stay true to our strengths. Our openers are quality players—they don’t need to slog, they need support and time to build. We can’t afford to be chasing the scoreboard too early. If we’re losing three or four in the powerplay, we’re only making it harder for the middle order. It’s about being smart, trusting the process, and building partnerships that win you games."
 

Ajinkya Rahane (Kolkata Knight Riders Captain):
"We came in with a clear mindset, a lot of thought went into our plans. Having spent a couple of years here in Chennai, both Moeen and Bravo had their say as well. We expected the surface to play a touch better, but it turned out a bit more sluggish than anticipated. That said, our plans came through beautifully tonight.

When it comes to what we had in store for CSK, I’ll keep that under wraps—still a long road in the tournament, and cards need to be kept close to the chest.

Swapping Johnson for Moeen? On a night like this, it felt like the right move. Moeen showed great maturity, especially considering he's been in and out of the XI. He stuck to his strengths and delivered under pressure. Varun and Sunny were outstanding—they completely owned the middle overs. Vaibhav and Harshit at the top were clinical. It was a total team effort.

On a personal note, I’ve been keeping things simple. Been grinding hard over the last two years, especially in this format, and now it’s all coming together.

We didn’t talk about net run rate at the start, but once we got a foothold in the game, we saw the opportunity. We pushed for a quick finish to give that NRR a healthy bump. It’s all about momentum from here—no more alternate wins, we want to string them together."
 

Sunil Narine (Player of the Match):
"That felt close to a complete performance. Just a small regret—I should’ve held on to that catch, Harshit was in for something special there.

For me, it’s always about sticking to my strengths. The moment you start reacting too much to what the batter is doing, you lose your edge. I keep things simple and back what I do best.

Conditions are part of the puzzle. You get used to how things behave with time—feel out the pitch early, assess the powerplay, and then go about executing the plans accordingly.

With the bat, my job is straightforward—give the team a flying start. It won’t come off every time, but the intent is always there. I’ll look to bring the same approach into the next game and keep contributing where I can."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Royal Challengers Bengaluru vs Delhi Capitals
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Delhi Capitals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Get ready for a thrilling showdown at the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bengaluru as the Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) host the Delhi Capitals (DC) in match number 24 of the TATA IPL 2025! The stakes are high, and the excitement is palpable as these two top teams clash in a battle for supremacy.

RCB have been on a tear, with impressive victories against top-notch opponents in Chennai, Mumbai, and Kolkata. Their only loss in the tournament came against the table-toppers Gujarat Titans. The batting unit has been led by the consistent Kohli, Patidar, and Salt, while the bowling department has shown promise with the trio of Hazlewood, Bhuvi, and Dayal.

Meanwhile, DC are riding high as the only unbeaten team in the tournament. They're looking to continue their momentum, and their journey has been marked by signs of brilliance from every individual. Ashutosh Sharma's match-winning performance in the first game, followed by Mitchell Starc's brilliant bowling display against SRH, and a thrilling win against CSK at the MA Chidambaram Stadium after 15 long years, have all contributed to their impressive start.

This high-octane encounter promises to be an electrifying one! Will DC continue their dominance and remain unbeaten, or will RCB halt their streak and claim their first home win of the season? The M. Chinnaswamy Stadium is buzzing with excitement, and the fans are eagerly waiting to witness this thrilling contest!



IPL Stats at Chinnaswamy STadium Since 2024:
 
 

Pitch Report | Danny Morrison & Varun Aaron

"We're back in the garden city — Bengaluru, baby! But a little concern in the air. There's cloud cover, we've had a light drizzle, and the covers were briefly on. It's Pitch No. 7 today — bang in the centre. That gives us 64 metres square and 73 metres straight, so some good hitting zones to work with tonight.The surface looks like a belter. There’s a bit of grass on it, but it’s mostly dry with some bare patches too. The heavy roller’s been in action, which will flatten it further. Last game on this pitch saw 200 runs put up — and with these short square boundaries and a lightning-fast outfield, expect fireworks again tonight."

???? Toss ????@DelhiCapitals won the toss and elected to bowl against @RCBTweets in Bengaluru.

Updates ?? https://t.co/h5Vb7sp2Z6#TATAIPL | #RCBvDC pic.twitter.com/mXzcfDp4LX

— IndianPremierLeague (@IPL) April 10, 2025
Matchsummary.PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs)
RCB:- 64/2 (10.66 rpo, 5x4, 4x6) || DC:- 39/3 (6.5 rpo, 5x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs)
RCB:- 53/4 (5.88 rpo, 2x4, 2x6) || DC:- 82/1 (9.11 rpo, 6x4, 4x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs)
RCB:- 46/1 (9.2 rpo, 2x4, 4x6)  || DC:- 48/0 (16.94 rpo, 4x4, 3x6) 
 

Ohhh what a night in the Garden City! Under the bright lights of the Chinnaswamy, KL Rahul lit it up with a knock dipped in pure gold as Delhi Capitals chased down 164 with ease to hand Royal Challengers Bengaluru a humbling six-wicket defeat.

RCB got off to a fiery start thanks to Phil Salt’s explosive 37 off 17, but once he was run out, the innings unraveled. Kuldeep Yadav spun a web with 2/17 and Vipraj Nigam turned heads with 2/18, helping restrict RCB to a modest 163. Tim David’s late burst (37* off 20) gave them something to bowl at, but oh boy — it was never enough.

Enter Rahul, the prodigal son of Bengaluru. From 30/3, he took charge like a man on a mission. A majestic 93 off 53 balls*, peppered with seven boundaries and six glorious sixes, silenced the home crowd. Stubbs played his part too with a fiery 38*. Delhi remain unbeaten, and Rahul? He’s batting like a man possessed! 

 

Rajat Patidar | RCB Captain:
"We misread the pitch. Thought it’d be a good batting deck, but it played differently. Our collapse from 80/1 to 90/4 really hurt us — that’s unacceptable with the kind of batting we have. We haven’t assessed conditions well and that cost us.
That said, Tim David’s been a huge plus, especially his finishing. Also, the fast bowlers were sharp with the new ball. We’re not diving deep into stats. For us, it’s about getting our cricket right — together."

 

Axar Patel | DC Captain:
"Winning four in a row feels great — the confidence is flowing in this unit. Tactically, we avoided using too many pacers in the powerplay, knowing RCB’s strength at the top. There was bounce and grip for the spinners and that helped.Vipraj has been brilliant. A calm guy, and gives me confidence to throw him the ball in any situation.As for KL Rahul, he just makes things easy. His adaptability is elite. That innings tonight — it was a masterclass in chasing. He’s been in red-hot form since the Champions Trophy." 
 


KL Rahul | Player of the Match:
"Being behind the stumps for 20 overs gave me real insight into the surface. It wasn’t dual-paced, but the ball was sticking. I just wanted to get off to a good start and then build from there.As a keeper, you observe what works and where to hit, and I used that to my advantage.
This is my home ground — I’ve played here a lot and always love coming back. I experiment in the nets, train to adapt to different wickets. That way it becomes second nature to adjust. You have to read the conditions, identify your scoring pockets, and stay sharp. That’s what worked today."

Matchsummary.MatchName: Gujarat Titans vs Rajasthan Royals
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Rajasthan Royals Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the grand theatre of cricket – the Narendra Modi Stadium – where strategy meets spectacle, and pressure turns coal into diamonds! We’ve got the Gujarat Titans locking horns with the Rajasthan Royals in what promises to be a cricketing epic!This venue isn’t just turf and stands – it’s alive!The pitch can flatter the pacers early, grip for the spinners in the middle, and then turn into a slippery slope with the dew late in the evening. It’s a surface that tests not just skill, but smarts!

Gujarat Titans have roared into second place riding on the power trio – Shubman Gill, Sai Sudharsan, and Jos Buttler – who’ve scored the majority of the team’s runs. But here's the catch – that middle order hasn’t been under the pump yet. If Rajasthan can crack that top three early, we’ll find out what the Titans are really made of!The Royals, meanwhile, are peaking at the right time! Jofra Archer is bowling thunderbolts again, and the spin duo of Hasaranga and Theekshana are weaving webs. And don’t sleep on the youngsters – Dhruv Jurel and Nitish Rana have been clutch in the middle. Yashasvi Jaiswal’s form is ticking upward too. Ooh, it’s simmering! With Mohammed Siraj firing on all cylinders and Rashid Khan bowling with venom, Gujarat has the tools. But this one’s going to be a chess match at 150 kmph. The team that reads the pitch quicker, holds their nerve longer, and finishes stronger – they’ll walk away with the points.

Get ready, folks. This isn’t just a match – it’s mayhem in the making!

 
IPL Stats at Narendra Modi Stadium Since 2024:


 

Pitch Report | Pommie Mbangwa & Simon Katich
“Welcome, folks — time to assess the conditions here at the Narendra Modi Stadium, and let me tell you, the outfield is an absolute dream. Smooth as silk, quick as a flash — it's like a billiards table out there. The square boundaries? One side’s 60 meters, the other 71. Straight down the ground? 73 meters. As a bowler, you’ve got to be very smart with your angles tonight.We’re on pitch seven — red soil base with a noticeable green tinge on top. But make no mistake, this is a belter! The surface has hosted four games across the last two seasons, and we’ve seen totals north of 220, even 230. That bounce and pace off the red soil make it a batter’s paradise. If you bat first, you've got to post a big score — because once the ball starts flying, there's no holding it back!Put runs on the board, apply scoreboard pressure. Just like we saw last night with Punjab Kings. The ball skids beautifully under lights, so defending becomes a bit easier once you've got 200-plus on the board.”

Gujarat Titans put on a high-class performance across departments to register a thumping 58-run win over the Rajasthan Royals at the Narendra Modi Stadium.

Sent in to bat, GT were powered by a masterful 82 off 53 from Sai Sudharsan, who anchored the innings with finesse and flair. He was well supported by Shahrukh Khan (36 off 20) and a fiery late cameo from *Rahul Tewatia (24 off 12)**. Titans posted a commanding 217/6, capitalizing on some indisciplined bowling by RR, with Tushar Deshpande (2/53) and Theekshana (2/54) taking the brunt of the damage.

In reply, RR faltered early — losing two wickets inside three overs. Despite a fighting 41 from skipper Sanju Samson and a crisp 52 from Hetmyer, the rest of the batting crumbled under scoreboard pressure. Prasidh Krishna (3/24) and Rashid Khan (2/37) spun a web around the middle order, while Sai Kishore closed it out with 2 late wickets.

Rajasthan were bowled out for 159 in 19.2 overs, with only Hetmyer offering any real resistance as partners fell around him. 

 

Sanju Samson | RR Captain: 
"We definitely gave away 15–20 runs more than we should have with the ball. That extra cushion really hurt us later.With Hetmyer at the crease, the boundaries were flowing — fours, sixes, everything — but losing my wicket at that stage really tilted the game. That’s where we lost the grip.Jofra gave us a great start, getting Shubman early, but then we drifted off-plan. We’ll have to sit down and reassess that tomorrow. Yes, after a loss, questions come up — should we have chased, should we have done something different? But as a team, we want to back ourselves to win games while chasing, not just when we bat first."  

 

Shubman Gill | GT Captain
"We put up a very good total. It wasn't easy early on — the ball was nipping around in the first 3–4 overs. Full credit to Sai and Jos, they batted tremendously to get us to that score. Honestly, we’d take 220 on this surface any day.Our fast bowlers are doing a tremendous job — everyone’s stepping up. When you can’t easily pick a Player of the Match, that’s the hallmark of a complete team effort.Captaincy becomes easy when you have this kind of bowling unit. Whoever I throw the ball to, they’re ready and hungry to deliver. And of course, having Ishi bhai (Ishant Sharma) around — someone who’s played 100 Tests — makes a big difference to the group.” 
 

Sai Sudharsan | Player of the Match:
"In the IPL, momentum at the start of the tournament is really important. So it's a joy to contribute and help the team get the win tonight.The pitch was seaming early on, so we had to assess quickly. You can’t take too much time in T20s, so we made the most of the second half of the powerplay. The plan was simple — keep wickets in hand, and it worked beautifully.There’s a clear understanding within the group. If we lose early wickets, the set batter takes responsibility. If not, we make sure to give the hitters a solid platform so they can explode in the final 5–7 overs.Personally, I always focus on what I can improve. I'm working on my game awareness and refining my skills. Honestly, I just try to keep my basics strong — and that’s helping me evolve into a more versatile batter.”

Matchsummary.MatchName: Punjab Kings vs Chennai Super Kings
Matchsummary.TossDetails: Punjab Kings Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
Matchsummary.PreMatchCommentary:
Fasten your seatbelts, folks! We’ve got a mouthwatering contest on our hands as Punjab Kings take on Chennai Super Kings at the brand-new Mullanpur cauldron! Two heavyweight franchises, both under pressure, both hungry for a turnaround—and make no mistake, this one’s going to be a firecracker!

Punjab Kings have blown hot and cold so far. Their campaign took a hit with a hefty loss against Rajasthan, but with Shreyas Iyer at the helm and young guns like Nehal Wadhera firing, they’ve got the firepower. Ricky Ponting will be urging his boys to bring the heat—especially with spin being their Achilles heel last time out.

On the other side, the mighty Chennai Super Kings are looking for answers. Three losses on the bounce, and questions being asked of the top order. MS Dhoni’s doing the job with the bat lower down, but CSK need their engine room to start firing. Ruturaj and the boys will know: you don’t win titles in April, but you sure can lose momentum.

Expect spin to play a big part, toss to be crucial, and pressure to be sky-high. Strap in. This isn't just a game—this is IPL theatre at its very best! 

 
 

Pitch Report | Daren Ganga and Michael Clarke:

 "We're in Chandigarh for Punjab Kings' second home game, where they'll be facing off against Chennai Super Kings. Both teams come into this match off losses. Notably, we’ve switched pitches. The boundaries are different now, with the square boundaries at 7m and the straight boundary stretching to 74m. Batters, especially right-handers, will likely target the leg side. Michael Clarke is with me. Looking at the pitch, it resembles the one used in Punjab Kings' match against the Royals. Dew doesn't seem like a factor tonight.Both wickets look similar, and though you can spot a few dry patches, the surface remained pretty steady on Saturday. I don’t think the toss will have a huge impact. The key here is the length of your deliveries. Overpitching is beneficial for the batters as the ball comes onto the bat nicely, allowing them to hit through the line. But if you bowl too short, especially with slower pace, it’ll play into the batters’ hands. Hitting the top of the stumps length is the sweet spot here. That’s the key in both the powerplay and at the death."

Punjab Kings put on a commanding show to notch their first home win of the season, defeating Chennai Super Kings by 18 runs in a high-scoring encounter.

Sent in to bat, Priyansh Arya stole the spotlight with a breathtaking 103 off just 42 balls, lighting up the powerplay and tearing into CSK’s attack. Despite a middle-order wobble, Shashank Singh (52 off 36)* and Marco Jansen (34 off 19)* added late firepower, pushing PBKS to a daunting 219/6. Arya’s strokeplay was ruthless — 9 sixes and 7 boundaries in a fearless inning that laid the foundation.

CSK’s chase began briskly with Rachin Ravindra (36) and Devon Conway (69 retired out) building a solid platform. But a mid-innings squeeze and regular wickets — including Dube (42) and Dhoni (27 off 12) — slowed their momentum. A tactical retire-out of Conway raised eyebrows, but even late fireworks from Dhoni and Jadeja couldn't bridge the gap as CSK finished at 201/5.

Lockie Ferguson (2/40) and Maxwell (1/11) delivered crucial breakthroughs, while Yash Thakur held his nerve at the death. With this win, PBKS not only get off the mark at home but also hand CSK a reality check in the race to the playoffs. 
 

Ruturaj Gaikwad | Chennai Super Kings Captain:
“In the last four games, dropped catches have been the real difference. Every time we miss one, the same batter adds 20–30 extra runs — that’s costly. If you take out the RCB game, our last three losses have come down to just two or three big hits.Credit to Priyansh — he played fearless cricket, took risks, and they paid off. Even though we kept picking wickets, they maintained the pressure and momentum. Maybe 10–15 runs fewer, with better execution and catching, and it could’ve been a different story.From a batting point of view, today was spot-on. Our best players against pace were up the order and made full use of the powerplay. Conway timed the ball well early on, but once we saw him slowing down, we made the call to bring in Jaddu for the finishing role.We’re emphasizing fielding — told the team to enjoy it, not feel nervous. One good catch or boundary save can lift the entire group. While you can have off days with bat or ball, fielding is all about mindset — and it’s something we must improve going forward.” 
 

Shreyas Iyer | Punjab Kings Captain:
“This is the template we’re looking to build — no matter the ground. We have variety, power, and great timing throughout our batting unit.Priyansh was simply outstanding today. I had a chat with him last match when he looked a bit unsure against Jofra. But today, he went out with total clarity. Backed his instincts, went after the ball when it was there, and played one of the best knocks I’ve seen in the IPL so far. That was a tactical call. Dube was set, Conway was still at the crease. We felt pace-off deliveries into the pitch would be more effective at that stage. Yuzi is a class bowler, no doubt, but sometimes you have to trust your gut in crunch moments — and it worked out today.We’re yet to put together a perfect game. Fielding is a mindset — once the boys start attacking the ball fearlessly, we’ll get there. We’ll regroup, train harder, and work on turning those half-chances into moments that win us matches.”

 

Priyansh Arya | Player of the Match:
“Sir, it feels out of this world. I’m really happy with my performance, but I’m even more focused on contributing more for the team going forwardThe intent was always to stay positive. I had a chat with Shreyas bhaiya before the game, and he told me — if it’s in your zone, go for it from ball one. That gave me the confidence to back my instincts.When Nehal came in, I asked if I should slow down, but he encouraged me to stick to my natural game — and that helped me stay in rhythm. CSK’s bowlers are top quality, any of them can challenge you, but I just wanted to trust my game and keep attacking.”
